TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. In view of ongoing and destabilising speculation in the media and Australian Labor Party circles regarding the leadership of the Government, can the Minister indicate when the Prime Minister intends to step down?
—The Prime Minister has made it perfectly clear that he will contest the next election, and I have absolutely nothing to add to that.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In view of that answer, will the Minister share with us whether or not a deal has been done, as we understand it has, between the Right and the Left that when the Prime Minister steps down in March Senator Richardson will get the Senate leadership and Senator Bolkus the deputy leadership?
—That is a wildly implausible scenario.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. In light of the announcement by the United States Secretary of State, James Baker, that the United States plans to ask the United Nations (UN) Security Council to meet on Thursday to consider an appropriate resolution which authorises the use of force to expel Iraq from Kuwait, can the Minister inform the Senate as to the Australian Government's views on this initiative? Have those views been communicated to the Bush Administration?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen reports today indicating that Secretary of State Baker does intend chairing a meeting of the Security Council on 29 November to discuss a draft resolution authorising the use of force, as a last resort, against Iraq. The text of the proposed draft resolution has not yet been circulated, but I understand from press reports that it will propose a deadline by which Iraq should withdraw from Kuwait. If Iraq fails to withdraw, member states would be asked to use `all necessary means' to implement the Security Council's resolutions on the crisis.

ANSWER.PARA: As for Australia's position on this, Australia has, of course, always supported a peaceful resolution to the crisis but, as I and the Prime Minister have indicated on a number of occasions, the military option does have to be kept on the table. If the military option does eventually have to be pursued in order to ensure Iraq's compliance with the Security Council's resolutions, then, as I have also made clear on a number of occasions, whether or not it is strictly necessary Australia would certainly prefer that there be endorsement of such action by a further specific Security Council resolution. Therefore, we would support a further move by the Security Council along the lines reportedly proposed by the United States to increase pressure on Iraq.

The fact is that, although economic sanctions are, on all the evidence available to us, now causing real hardship in Iraq, Saddam Hussein has neither withdrawn from Kuwait nor abided by the norms of international law, particularly as regards the holding of foreign nationals in Iraq and Kuwait against their will. An ultimatum resulting from a Security Council resolution authorising the use of force would give Saddam Hussein a last opportunity for a peaceful settlement to this crisis. Australia, of course, would urge him very strongly to take that opportunity. The United States Administration is very well aware of Australia's policy on the Iraq-Kuwait crisis. We would expect specific discussions to take place with us on this latest move once a draft text was circulated for comment. Australia is not, of course, presently a member of the Security Council itself, but our delegation to the UN in New York will continue to follow the Council's deliberations very closely and report developments to the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question follows the previous question and the answer that has just been given. In view of the fact that the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade now indicates that the Government will support a Security Council resolution authorising force, I ask: will the Government go one step further and use its good offices to lobby for that, in particular with Security Council members within our region such as Malaysia? Now that we are looking at the instance of using force to end this crisis, has Australia been approached to participate in operations against Iraq in the event that such a resolution is passed?

—As to the first point, we would be guided by the United States of America as the sponsor of such a Security Council resolution as to how it might be best progressed in New York in the Security Council. We would, of course, stand ready to assist in any way that was thought appropriate after such consultation in moving it forward. As to whether we have been approached to assist, no, there has been no approach in that respect. At this stage I do not think I should, so far as future questions of this kind are concerned, be drawn into the position of having to respond to that sort of question. I am not anticipating any particular approach, but it is very difficult in these situations to give a blow-by-blow description of a course of ongoing consultations which will undoubtedly be occurring in the context of a resolution of this kind.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. It concerns the Government's agreement with the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) to replace the first wage adjustment under accord mark 6 with personal income tax cuts. Can the Minister advise the Senate on the benefits this tax-wage trade-off will confer on Australia's economic situation? Can he also advise honourable senators whether this is yet another instance of the continuing success of the accord system between the Government and the ACTU?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —During the last sitting week I said that the September quarter, for which the consumer price index (CPI) was 0.7 per cent, was the fifth successive quarter in which the inflation rate in Australia had come down and that, in view of that, it was opportune for the Government to look at the innovative use it could make of having such a low figure. Of course, we have done that. Last Tuesday the Treasurer and I announced a proposal to buy out the September quarter wage round with a tax cut. Under accord mark 6 the September quarter was marked down for its CPI increase. That CPI increase was to be taken in the form of a wage increase as the first step under accord mark 6. The second step under accord mark 6 was for there to be, six months later, a $12 per week increase and then for guidelines to be handed down by the Industrial Relations Commission for enterprise based bargaining, those guidelines to provide for no double counting and for achieved productivity and profitability gains. As well, superannuation was provided.

ANSWER.PARA: The proposal that we have consolidated with ACTU officers-a proposal we expect the ACTU Executive to adopt this week-is that we buy out the September quarter wage round; that the $12 will click in about mid-May; that there will be a one per cent superannuation increase from 1 July next year, another one per cent from 1 May 1992 and another one per cent from 1 May 1993; and that there will be enterprise bargaining guidelines for achieved productivity and profitability gains.

That is done in the expectation that the national wage case decision, which we hope would endorse all of those changes, will be available to us before Christmas. The wage-tax trade-off means that a worker on $30,000 a year will receive an extra tax cut on top of the tax cuts provided for in this year's Budget of $2.95, or the equivalent of a $4.85 wage increase. If one takes the two tax cuts together for the same worker, that would mean a $10.80 per week tax cut in lieu of an $18 per week wage rise. That has been hailed around Australia as a welcome innovation by the Government and one that will lock in a lower level of inflation.

It effectively means that there is now a 12 months wage pause in Australia. The last structural efficiency adjustment was due on 1 March this year and there will not be another wage increase until mid-May next year. However, living standards will be maintained by virtue of the tax cut and purchasing power will remain. It means that our target for inflation in this year's Budget of 6 per cent will be achieved or, indeed, undershot. It means as well that Australia's inflation level will be going down at the time when the inflation levels of every other country in the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development are trending upwards. That can only be of advantage to our trading position. It means that the aggregate wage outcome for the year has been revised downwards from 7 per cent to 6.25 per cent as a consequence of this agreement; meaning that the total wages bill for the budgetary year will be lower.

It proves once again that if one does not have a wages policy-as the Opposition does not-one cannot regulate and manage the economy. We have a wages policy, by virtue of the accord, that enables us to manage the economy in order to do things of this nature-things which are to the benefit of the economy and the wider Australian community and things that have been universally acclaimed by all of the commentators. They have all praised the Government for this. Only that big sook and wet blanket, Dr Hewson, has opposed it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I preface my question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade by noting that the use of nuclear weapons against Iraq has been described by United States (US) Defence Secretary Cheney as a possible, if unfavoured, option and was openly endorsed by the Kuwaiti Foreign Minister on his recent visit to Australia. I further note that Secretary Cheney today said that Iraq may be five to 10 years away from possessing a deliverable nuclear weapon. I ask the Minister: firstly, does he agree that the possible use of nuclear weapons is being raised as part of the process, identified by Morris West in yesterday's Sunday Herald, of conditioning us to war and desensitising us to its consequences? Secondly, does he also agree that Iraq's nuclear ambitions and those of other would-be nuclear powers will be increased by US threats to use nuclear weapons? Thirdly, will the Government convey to the Bush Administration its opposition to the use of nuclear weapons and its intention to withdraw Australian warships from the Gulf region if nuclear weapons are used there? Fourthly, will the Government support a United Nations initiative to maintain a ban on nuclear cooperation with Iraq after it withdraws from Kuwait?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not propose to speculate as to what the motivation might be of those who are dangling, as it were, the use of a nuclear weapon option-although some motives spring pretty rapidly to mind, other than that which was the subject of comment by Mr West. As to what Iraq might do in response to such a threat, again, I do not think it would be helpful or useful for me to speculate about that.

ANSWER.PARA: As to Australia's attitude on nuclear weapons, our position, of course, is perfectly clear: we do not support the use of nuclear weapons in any context whatsoever. It is difficult to believe that the situation in the Gulf could possibly be an exception to that. I do not think it necessarily follows from that position, however, that we would feel obliged to take a different view about the whole justification for the situation in Iraq and the appropriateness of an international response to it. It is a matter of evaluating that in view of all of the circumstances as they prevail at the time.

So far as nuclear cooperation with Iraq is concerned, I am not sure that I fully caught the import of the last part of Senator Powell's question but certainly I would hope and expect that the international community would be utterly unwilling in any circumstances whatsoever to extend nuclear cooperation to Iraq in the circumstances of a known disposition on the part of its Government to put together a nuclear weapon.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question without notice is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations, and it is about the wage-tax trade-off under the accord. What has been the response to the initiative announced last week between the Government and the Australian Council of Trade Unions? Has the attention of the Minister been drawn to Dr Hewson's description of this initiative as no more than `a diversion'? Has his attention also been drawn to reports of comments by Dr Hewson's spokesperson on industrial relations welcoming the deflationary aspects of the initiative? Can the Minister advise honourable senators whether the trade-off is just a diversion, as Dr Hewson thinks, or an effective weapon against inflation, as Mr Howard says?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The response to the wage-tax trade-off is manifested best by a selection of newspaper editorials responding to the announcement. The Australian Financial Review of 21 November, in its editorial, said the trade-off is:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . a clever move to achieve a one-off stepdown in prices growth and highlights the value of a flexible wage lever in the Government's policy kit bag . . . The new wage deal is a welcome and sensible step in bringing down the nation's inflation rate.
The Courier-Mail of the same day said, referring to Paul Keating:

At one stroke, he has emasculated the Opposition on wage policy, removed the counter-productive quality of the Accord process to build inflation into wage bargaining, and helped restart demand as a component of the economy.
The Launceston Examiner said it was sensible and timely and it will help to turn the economy around. The Canberra Times said the wage-tax deal was an economic coup and went on:
The . . . Government and the Australian Council of Trade Unions can only be described as both politically and economically inspired.
The Age of 21 November said:
Clever wage-tax deal benefits all.
It went to opine in its editorial that it is
. . . a timely and clever idea that should benefit everyone without any off-setting losses. The Government deserves credit for proposing it and the ACTU for accepting it.
The Adelaide Advertiser of the next day, 22 November, said:
The new wage-tax deal is a welcome initiative. It will curb but not cure inflation and provide a circuit-breaker for business.
The Sydney Morning Herald said:

The critics can't have it both ways. They can't argue that the economy couldn't afford a wage increase at this time and then argue this deal won't make a great difference to labour costs and therefore employment levels.
In this sense the Government has cut the ground out from under the feet of the Opposition.
In his opinion column in the Herald-Sun, George Megalogenis, the economics editor, said:
In doing so, Mr Keating delivered a win for businesses, for workers and the economy.

I could go on with quotes from the Northern Territory News, an unlikely source of praise for a Labor government; from the Townsville Bulletin, similarly an unlikely source of praise; from the Melbourne Age; from the Herald-Sun, which said, `Keating plays a winner'; and from the Sydney Morning Herald, which said:
Tax/wage trade-off makes economic, political sense.
Indeed, Mr Ian Spicer of the Confederation of Australian Industry said the accord:
. . . is in the best interests of Australia's economy.

If I can conclude, Mr President, John Howard in a radio interview is reported to have said these grudging words of approval, `To the extent it cuts inflation, I welcome it', and `Under the accord environment it was the logical thing to do'. Only that big sook and wet blanket, Dr John Hewson, said it was a diversion, a last gamble, and it would fail. Who is out of step?

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. What arrangements will the Foreign Minister make for Australia's representation in Ireland and the Holy See during the time that Ambassador Burke is required to appear before the Royal Commission into WA Inc.?
—I have not given any consideration to that question and I am not sure that I should be obliged to, but I will look at it in light of the question.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. I refer to various media reports over the weekend about the National Crime Authority's change of direction under its new Chairman, Mr Justice Phillips. Could the Minister inform the Senate of the details of this change of direction?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased that Senator Faulkner asked a question on this matter because the intergovernmental committee of Ministers representing all jurisdictions met in Alice Springs last Friday and received a report from Mr Justice Phillips, the newly installed Chairman of the National Crime Authority. We were greatly heartened by what we heard from him and were therefore able to give him unanimous support in the new directions in which he is leading the National Crime Authority.

ANSWER.PARA: The reason for our unanimous support fell into two categories. One was as to the more cooperative, collaborative approach which Mr Justice Phillips promised would be the style of the National Crime Authority in dealing with other law enforcement agencies at the State and Federal levels. The various jurisdictions are sometimes bedevilled by turf disputes and jealousy, and that cannot be allowed to impede nationwide law enforcement against organised crime, particularly drug trafficking and white collar crime of a major nature. That particular emphasis on cooperation and collaboration--

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you admit it has been in the past?

—This will be a new and very welcome emphasis. As to the actual substance of the work of the National Crime Authority, there will be a shift in emphasis away from-but not excluding-major drug trafficking and towards white collar crime. Of course, to put them into those two exclusive categories is somewhat misleading. Money laundering is a very good example of a bridge between the two, where those who engage in major drug trafficking launder the proceeds of crime in various enterprises and engage in white collar crime as part of their overall criminal activity.

ANSWER.PARA: I think the general Australian community now recognises that, with the improvement in the efficiency and, indeed, the integrity of various law enforcement agencies throughout the Commonwealth, there is now a capacity in those other agencies to take up much of the drug trafficking investigation which was a feature of the National Crime Authority under the leadership of its first Chairman, Mr Justice Stewart. I believe the new emphasis in relation to white collar crime is very timely and very welcome.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is largely just a change of fashion.

— It is not, as Senator Hill has interjected, largely a change of fashion. I believe there is real substance here, and I believe that, with the new emphasis on white collar crime, together with the work being undertaken by the Australian Securities Commission, one has the capacity to make a very cohesive and concentrated attack on that type of criminal activity which defrauds the tax base of revenue and which leads to the undermining of public confidence and investor confidence in much of the commercial and trading life of Australia, both domestically and overseas.

ANSWER.PARA: I believe that with this new approach this Parliament can take the same attitude as did the various Ministers from the various jurisdictions in Alice Springs last Friday, and give Mr Justice Phillips a fair go in settling into his new responsibilities and his fresh approach. I believe that the Parliamentary Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority has a real role to play in that support and I am sure it will be briefed by Mr Justice Phillips along the same lines as was the intergovernmental committee. I think it would be useful if the Parliamentary Joint Committee considered, not so much raking over dying embers of past disputes, which I agree were matters of concern, but looking to the matters which will be canvassed by the National Crime Authority and investigated by it as it assembles admissible evidence in relation to major criminal activity in the future.

Senator Spindler indicated last week in a question to me-and I think I responded constructively-that if we can get the balance right between the Parliamentary Joint Committee and the National Crime Authority in relation to the matters which the National Crime Authority can disclose and matters about which the Parliamentary Joint Committee can legitimately ask questions and report on to this Parliament, we will have a more accountable, less secretive organisation which, although vested with extraordinary powers to investigate organised crime, nevertheless needs to be accountable in our sort of democracy. I believe we can reach that balance and I hope the Parliamentary Joint Committee can agree with the intergovernmental committee of Ministers that the National Crime Authority, under its new leadership, will now enter a more constructive and even democratic phase of its activity within the Australian community and ought to enjoy our full support.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer the Minister to the Prime Minister's answer to a question asked in the House on 15 November by the Leader of the Opposition, in which the Prime Minister stated:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . in terms of unemployment peaking and at what level, neither I nor any other person is able to say.

I also refer the Minister to statements made by the Secretary of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, Mr Kelty, in an interview with the Age today, in which he said that unemployment `would top 8 per cent for a few months'. Does the Minister agree with the Prime Minister or with Mr Kelty? If he agrees with the Prime Minister, how does he consider it was possible for the Treasurer to say last Thursday that one important reason for an estimated $1.5 billion shortfall in the Budget surplus this year will be higher unemployment benefits?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Our track record in unemployment growth has been very well proven. Employment growth has been almost five times the average annual rate recorded during the previous Government's term. That is a statistic that cannot be repeated too often. We have generated over 1.6 million jobs since we took office, of which over 90 per cent were in the private sector. That is not a statistic which can be repeated too often. It is the case, more recently, that the labour market has been subdued-employment did fall a marginal 0.1 per cent in the latest Australian Bureau of Statistics labour force figures-to fall some 0.4 per cent in the three months to October, compared with the previous three months. This is hardly a collapse in the labour market. There clearly has not been a major shake-out. It is nowhere near the 2.6 per cent collapse in employment which was recorded over five consecutive quarters during the 1982-83 recession, which Senator Short may well recall, since he has some of the responsibility of his Government for that.

ANSWER.PARA: The success of the accord in preventing a wages blow-out has helped prevent a collapse in employment. The accord has achieved unprecedented real wage moderation in the face of a booming economy--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. I think the Minister has had ample opportunity to consider the question that he was asked. So far he has simply presented an irrelevant diatribe on what he regards as the benefits of the accord and a few other aspects of the Government's employment track record. The question related to a statement made by the Prime Minister in the House recently, a statement made by Mr Kelty today and some remarks made last week by Mr Keating. The Minister has touched on none of those and I invite you to direct him to answer that part of the question only. If he does not do that, he is irrelevant and out of order.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—Thank you, Mr President. I will answer the question in exactly the way in which I intended. The rise in unemployment rates since late 1989 was largely due to the significant rise in labour force participation rather than any other consideration. However, the slowdown in demand growth necessary to reduce the current account deficit cannot be achieved without affecting both output and the labour market. Statements by Mr Kelty and others reflect that reality. The Budget forecasts an increase in unemployment this year, although it should start to decline next year as the economy recovers. Beyond that, I do not propose to speculate about what the particular figures are or may be.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for that non-answer. He obviously picked up the wrong briefing paper. I ask again: Does he agree with the Prime Minister or Mr Kelty as to whether unemployment has peaked or will peak at a particular rate? In the light of his answer, I also ask: Will the Government take urgent steps to bring down a mini-Budget to deal with Australia's worsening economic condition and the undermining of key Budget forecasts which were implicitly confirmed by the Treasurer in his statement last Thursday?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not propose to comment specifically on particular peak rates or levels, whether on the invitation of Senator Short or anyone else. On the particular question of the May economic statement, which was the subject of the further supplementary--
—But did you see the program?
—I will program you in a minute.

ANSWER.PARA: Honourable senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —There is certainly one zombie in this place and he is sitting on the Opposition front bench.
—Order!

—It is far too early to speculate on whether we will bring down a May economic statement. Given the Opposition's failure to support the Government's position on family allowance assets tests, we have no faith in its commitment to the kind of expenditure and restraint that would be incorporated in such a statement.

—I refer the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs to media reports about new gun controls agreed on by the Australian Police Ministers Council last week. What will be the effect of these controls on the community?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator West for her question, because it is important to note that the Commonwealth will act in accordance with the decision of the Australian Police Ministers Council in Alice Springs last Thursday to ban the import of certain military style semi-automatic self-loading rifles (SLRs) into the Australian community. The firearms to be prohibited from import are simply those which have been designed-or which try to imitate them-by the Soviet Union or Chinese military forces or militias for the purpose of killing other human beings. I believe that all honourable senators would agree that those types of weapons ought to find no place being imported into the Australian community.

ANSWER.PARA: The New Zealand Minister for Police was with us at that meeting in Alice Springs and he indicated and applauded his great support for this decision. As honourable senators know, a Russian military style semi-automatic weapon was used in the terrible massacre which occurred very recently in New Zealand. Indeed, the killer had in his arsenal the type of Chinese style military weapon that is being imported at the moment into New South Wales.

Having said that, I think it is important to allay and put to rest some of the fears and misgivings which legitimate hunters, recreational shooters and some landowners have in regard to the exact definition of what will be banned from import. The Ministers quite clearly decided that those SLRs which have a magazine capacity of five rounds or an integrated magazine will be permitted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Didn't you make a press statement on this issue?

—If Senator Newman will allow me to complete my remarks, she will see that I am adding to any statement I may have made from Alice Springs. For example, Mr Ted Pickering, the Minister for Police and Emergency Services in the New South Wales Government, has said that a hunter of feral pigs in New South Wales can be faced with the prospect of confronting such a fierce animal with only a one-shot shotgun. That is absolute nonsense, because SLRs of a certain capacity will be permitted, and I believe that responsible shooters, hunters and landowners will applaud this particular decision.

ANSWER.PARA: We have received great support from all jurisdictions, apart from New South Wales. The Northern Territory, for example, where the Chief Minister, Mr Marshall Perron, gave the earliest and strongest support for this particular ban, allows hunting in relation to the destruction of feral animals. Mr Perron was quite happy with this particular ban which I have described.

The various shooters' organisations have been given a privileged position in regard to the list of those categories of firearms which will be permitted for import. For their endorsed disciplines and various competitions, they will in fact indicate which hand guns or rifles ought to be allowed in so that they can fulfil their competitive shooting needs. As I say, hunters, recreational shooters and landowners will have access to other firearms as appropriate.

I believe that the banning of Chinese Red Army militia style weapons of this very lethal kind ought to be welcomed by the Australian community, as indeed it has been by all jurisdictions except New South Wales. I believe that the Senate itself, having taken a great interest in the shaping and moulding of Australian society in the future, particularly in regard to questions of violence, will itself applaud this particular move.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. I refer the Minister to the report released today by the Centre for International Economics and commissioned by the Wool into the Twenty-first Century Committee, known as the Stoeckel report, and its main recommendation that the wool floor price be abolished. Can the Minister give an assurance to the 65,000 woolgrowers of Australia that the Government will reject this report, and will the Minister categorically reaffirm the Government's total and unequivocal support for the plan of the Wool Council of Australia and the Australian Wool Corporation for maintaining the floor price?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Boswell refers to a report which, I understand, was released today by the Centre for International Economics, a report into wool pricing commissioned by a group of New South Wales graziers and, I think, the Pastoralists and Graziers Association of Western Australia. I have not read the report, nor have I considered it, nor am I in a position to respond to it in detail. But I do understand that it does contain a recommendation which argues for the abandonment of the wool floor price as a measure to restore global demand.

ANSWER.PARA: I also understand that Sir William Gunn has said that abandoning the floor price would devastate the wool industry in Australia and be a mortal blow to the Australian economy. Those views have been endorsed by the grower organisation, the Wool Council of Australia, which has specifically endorsed Sir William's views.

As far as the Australian Government is concerned, the current situation is that the Wool Corporation, in consultation with the Wool Council of Australia, has already announced that the reserve price for wool next year will be 700c per kilo. The Minister would have a power to intervene to alter that arrangement only if there were disagreement between either the Wool Council or the Australian Wool Corporation. As a measure of this Government's respect for the industry, there is no intention to intervene where there is an agreement. We support the current situation. We have no intention of changing it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support. The Minister will be aware of extensive concern about the potential for an oil spill in the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park. Can the Minister detail what steps the Government is taking to protect the reef from possible damage by commercial shipping?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —This question, of course, does have direct relevance to Senator Reynolds, but I am quite sure that the initiative that Australia took recently would be welcomed by every member of the Senate. The Great Barrier Reef is unique in that it is the largest system of corals and associated life forms in the world. Australia has been pressing for some time for enhanced measures to protect it.

ANSWER.PARA: I am pleased to advise the Senate that last week Australia was successful in a major diplomatic effort to gain compulsory pilotage of ships on the Great Barrier Reef. A meeting of the Marine Environment Protection Committee of the International Maritime Organisation (IMO) agreed to identify the Great Barrier Reef as a particularly sensitive area. This was the first such declaration by the IMO of any such area in the world.

This is simply not a question of symbolism; it has a real effect. All of the major shipping nations of the world will be required by their governments to instruct ships flying their flags to act in accordance with Australia's pilotage arrangements for the Great Barrier Reef. Amendments will be made to the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act which will require all ships which pose a potential hazard to the reef to carry a pilot when navigating the northern part of the inner reef and Hydrographers Passage off Mackay. This requirement will apply to all ships in excess of 70 metres in length and to loaded oil tankers, chemical carriers and liquefied gas carriers, irrespective of their length.

Also an integral component of the Government's strategy is a special oil spill contingency plan for the reef called Reefplan, which is developed especially for protection of the reef. As part of this plan, the Commonwealth Government is currently engaged in a major upgrading of the stockpiles of pollution equipment contained at Townsville. There will be in excess of $1m worth of equipment located in Townsville when that upgrade is completed.

In addition, the Great Barrier Reef has been included in the World Heritage List and is also recognised in the International Convention for the Prevention of Pollution from Ships-that is, the MARPOL Convention. All of these initiatives together, I am pleased to say, provide a higher degree of protection to the Great Barrier Reef than any other sensitive maritime region in the world.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Industrial Relations to the current meat industry dispute in Queensland and Victoria-a dispute which has seriously affected 11 export meatworks in Victoria alone, which has cost 137,000 working days in the last 18 months, which has cost in excess of $85m in meat export earnings and which is currently costing between $1m and $2m per day. Approximately two weeks ago, Deputy President Riordan directed the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union (AMIEU) not to strike. I repeat: he directed the union not to strike. In view of the total disregard by the AMIEU of this direction, will the Federal Government, at the Australian Industrial Relations Commission hearing on 28 November, be intervening in support of the Meat and Allied Trades Federation, firstly to have a bans clause inserted into the award and, secondly, to have all preferences to unionists removed from the award so that these abattoirs can employ people who are prepared to work and get our meat exports moving again; or will the Government stand idly by and see further damage to our international reputation as a trader and, by default, endorse the abuse of the Industrial Relations Commission by the AMIEU, which is nothing short of anarchy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate the conscientiousness with which Senator Crane has put one point of view in the case of a quite serious industrial dispute in Australia. It should be said right at the start that the Australian Government is presiding over the lowest level of industrial disputation that has ever occurred in this country since the Australian Bureau of Statistics began keeping statistics on person days lost per thousand employees. Therefore, we are not talking about an industrial dispute in which there is a whole environment, if you like, across the board of industrial disputation. This has meant that we have been able to concentrate our efforts in creating industrial harmony by looking at the sectors that are particularly plagued. Unfortunately, it has to be said that the meat industry area is one of those.

ANSWER.PARA: As a consequence, the Australian Industrial Relations Commission is conducting an inquiry into the meat industry. The purpose of that inquiry, amongst other things, is to find out how to achieve a better industrial relationship in that industry, given its particular seasonal features, the tally system that applies and the far-flung regional locations of much of that industry around Australia.

Also as part of that inquiry, the Australian Government is sponsoring a tripartite union, employer and government overseas mission to look at best practice in other countries and to find models in which we can learn lessons to improve our own industrial management for the industry. It is against that background that this question arises. It is not to say that we do not treat this dispute as serious-we will. I will certainly consider the position of the Australian Government in terms of this matter. I do not think it is appropriate simply to proceed from a one-sided viewpoint and imagine, therefore, that all the elements of that one-sided viewpoint are right. The best course of action in cases like this is to allow the Industrial Relations Commission to do its job. That is far and away the preferred position of the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I want to repeat my question in terms of allowing the Industrial Relations Commission to do its work. Two weeks ago President Riordan instructed the AMIEU not to strike over this matter. What action does the Government intend to take in the hearing in two days time in terms of this blatant abuse of the law which is occurring?

—As I said, I will consider what position we will take. The provisions of the Act are provisions over which Deputy President Riordan is eminently suited to preside. It should be his judgment as to what action should be taken. If there is a need to enter into his considerations a public interest dimension, that is what I will consider. The parties-the employers, the unions and the Commission-all have a right within the procedures of the Commission to bring this matter to resolution. It is for Deputy President Riordan to make what decision he thinks appropriate in the circumstances, having weighed the facts.
—He has.
—The honourable senator cannot say that.
— He has made the direction.

—If there is-as it is suggested by Senator Crane-a blatant flouting of that suggestion, it is also within the power of the Deputy President to consider what action he takes about it. He is the right person to make that consideration and he should do so.

—My question was to be directed to Senator Button but I will now direct it to the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Has the Minister noted that the winning car in the Solar Challenge was powered by cells designed by Professor Martin Green of the University of New South Wales and that Professor Green's most recent photovoltaic cells are the most efficient in the world? Has the Minister further noted that it was reported that Professor Green has had to rely on substantial funding for his work from the United States of America, that the cells actually used in the Spirit of Biel were manufactured by Telefunken in West Germany and that the cells will be commercially manufactured by BP Solar Australia Pty Ltd in Spain, not in Australia? What, if anything, is the Minister doing or will he do to ensure that this leading technology, which addresses directly the most urgent environmental problem the world faces and has the potential to rival in importance the development of the computer, does not go the way of so many other excellent Australian initiatives before it, namely, disappears overseas from where we will have to buy it back?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have to confess that I did not notice, as the question prefaced, that the particular winning car had its component parts designed, proven, manufactured or fitted in those various locales that were mentioned. But the key point of the question seems to me the last part. The Australian Government maintains NERDDC-the National Energy Research, Development and Demonstration Council-through which it funds alternative energy research, among other things, but particularly alternative energy research where promising technologies are available and where a commercial interest exists to help develop and apply those technologies.

ANSWER.PARA: I am not sure whether any Commonwealth funds were used in the context of this particular vehicle or in the context of other vehicles in the Solar Challenge. It remains true that what we are concerned to see is the development of alternative energy sources-but in a commercial way; in a way in which they are not attracting wholesale subsidies and are, thus, artificially supported but rather in a way in which they can succeed in a commercial setting and in the marketplace. I do not know whether that answers all of the honourable senator's long question. I will study the question. If there are other elements of it, I will refer them to Senator Button to answer on his return.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I would like to read one sentence from the Australian of Thursday, 22 November 1990, which states:

QUESTION.PARA: The decision to manufacture cells in Spain first-
that is, the production of laser cells by BP Solar Australia Pty Ltd-
was taken because Australia did not have the scientific infrastructure to initiate production.

I wonder whether the Minister would comment on why Australia does not have the scientific infrastructure after seven years of this Labor Government which prides itself on Australia becoming the clever country?

TALK.START.PARA: —I have just said that we have a vigorous program of encouraging innovation in scientific research in the area of alternative energy-the NERDCC program. I forget the amount of funds but certainly tens of millions of dollars have been put out for encouragement of research during our period of office. But, as I said in closing in my last answer, I will refer the honourable senator's question to Senator Button to see whether he has anything to add to my answer.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to Senator McMullan's comment and comfort from the National Taxation Liaison Group on my private members' Income Tax Assessment (Substantiation Requirements) Amendment Bill 1990, where he stated:

QUESTION.PARA: There was broad consensus at the National Taxation Liaison Group at which this matter was discussed with the representatives of, for example, tax, accounting and legal bodies that it was not appropriate to amend the law.
Further, he stated:
When we had that discussion with them, their view was that it was not appropriate to amend the law and that is a view that at this stage the Government shares.

I ask, firstly, did the minutes accurately reflect the view of the National Taxation Liaison Group? Secondly, was this in fact the consensus of the meeting, as stated by Senator McMullan? Thirdly, how could Senator McMullan claim `we had discussions' when neither he nor the Government were members of the Group? Fourthly, following the Australian Taxation Office decision now to apply the law with commonsense, could the Minister confirm that the National Taxation Liaison Group endorses the practice of the Australian Taxation Commissioner whereby the Australian Taxation Office does not apply the law laid down by the Parliament and opposes the notion that Australian Taxation Office decisions should be subject to review? Finally, does the Minister agree that the Senate was misled?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not in a position to make a judgment about whether the Senate was misled or not, and I work on the assumption that it was not, by someone as accurate, as determined and as dedicated as Senator McMullan. I do not have a brief on the subject and I am unable to shed any light on any matter of substance that Senator Watson has asked me. I will seek an answer from the Treasurer or anyone who may know something about it and endeavour to get an answer on the record shortly.

—My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health. Can the Minister advise the Senate of the number of disabled people who are likely to lose the opportunity to participate in sheltered workshops under the Federal Government's cuts proposed by Minister Howe at the recent convention of the Australian Council for Rehabilitation of Disabled? Is the Government prepared to ignore comments made by the President of ACROD, Ms Felicity Purdy, who has stated that the severely disabled would in many instances be disadvantaged by the 1986 Act? Does the Government not appreciate that in this time of growing unemployment, there is an increasing need to support the disabled and the sheltered workshops which for many are their only opportunity of making a meaningful contribution to society?

—I am unable to give any specific answer to Senator Calvert in relation to his concern, except to say that I believe Mr Howe should not be interpreted in a way which would lead to severe detrimental impact on those who are suffering from the disabilities which are of concern to Senator Calvert and particularly, of course, to their families, friends and those who support them. The fact is that the Government wishes that the persons who presently find employment in those particular workshop situations have the opportunity to move into other forms of more open employment, and that type of transition is encouraged by the Government's policies. But as to the exact impact of the remarks made by Mr Howe during the week, I will have to ask him to give a further considered response to Senator Calvert.

—My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Land Transport. Can he advise us of the present position regarding the implementation of the Inter-State Commission report Road Use Charges and Vehicle Registration: A National Scheme, as it relates to the enormous proposed increases in charges for road transport in northern and western Queensland and in other remote areas of Australia? Can he assure the Senate that the implementation of any recommendations in the Inter-State Commission report will occur only after they have been fully debated in this Parliament?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter of the Inter-State Commission report, which has been canvassed at some length in the Senate chamber already, is of concern to people in remote Australia, as Senator Macdonald has just said. The current situation is that at the last Australian Transport Advisory Council (ATAC) meeting-which I think was in Hobart-there was a proposal to establish a number of working groups with State governments to further discuss this issue, and that is precisely where the proposals are at the moment.

ANSWER.PARA: The difficulty that we are currently faced with, and I have particular sympathy in this regard for States such as New South Wales, is that State governments that have hitherto tried to be responsible in their charging regimes in respect of road use, and have tried to cope with what everyone acknowledges is a major problem in this country-that is, how to provide the extraordinarily expensive national system of roads with a population of 17 million people and 3 1/2 million square miles to build it across-have been penalised because of the current fractured system of charging.

Of course, it is a particular problem for States like New South Wales. A massive amount of traffic runs across the roads of that State flowing, for example, from Victoria to Queensland and vice versa. The revenue gained as a result of that road use does not accrue to New South Wales, and any attempt by government, such as the New South Wales Government, to bring in a realistic system of charging would simply result in the trucking companies concerned moving the headquarters of their operations to a State where the road charges are less. It is a major problem that everyone acknowledges.

The Inter-State Commission's report has been accepted in regard to the principle that it is attacking, which is that we need a national system. The problem that exists with State-Federal relationships in this country has a major economic impact on this country, particularly in the area of transportation.

That is the current situation. These discussions are being advanced. I know that members of my own Caucus are having input into these discussions through the working groups that have been put together. I know that they are actively involved in coming back to future meetings of ATAC and reporting on how the matter is going to be resolved. I am heartened--

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the Premiers Conference?

—In response to Senator Boswell's interjection, in my view, the matter probably will be resolved at a special Premiers Conference. I suspect that it will take a decision by the leaders of governments, both State and Federal, finally to achieve the breakthrough that is required. It is an urgent problem. It is a problem that is currently being addressed, I think, in the most appropriate way possible by the responsible Minister. No doubt the Senate will, at an appropriate time, fully debate the matter when it is clearer as to what the outcome of these groups' deliberations will be.
—My question is directed to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs.
—Mr President, I take a point of order. This is not appropriate. Senator Tate passed that question to Senator Faulkner who then passed it on to Senator Giles to ask. It is a misuse of Question Time.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—Is the Minister aware that fire authorities believe that certain materials used in upholstered furniture have been associated with deaths and injuries in household fires? Is the Government planning any action to improve the safety of furniture commonly found in Australian homes?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would have thought that this answer would be of interest to Senator Walters because it provides for the use of a Tasmanian based facility in order to carry out this very important testing of furniture, which is of importance to the safety of all Australian households and, indeed, many offices.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. As I have already indicated, this is an abuse of Question Time. If the Minister wants to make a statement on an important issue after Question Time, he can do so.
—Order! The question was in order. It is not an abuse of Question Time and I ask the Minister to answer the question.

—Mr President, I thank you for rebutting that erroneous point of order by Senator Walters. The question of fire in the home and the contribution of furniture as an ignition point for those fires is, of course, a matter of grave concern, not only as to the fabric covering but also as to the foams which are now so often used in furnishings in Australia, because of the toxic fumes and gases that they can produce.
—It is a form of pollution.

—As Senator Richardson says, it is a form of pollution, but in this case so toxic that it can be not only injurious but also, in some cases, fatal. This is of great concern. The fact is that the Furniture Manufacturers Association of Australia and the Plastic Industry Association have come to an agreement in relation to these particular voluntary safety standards for the flammability of furnishings in Australia. I believe this is to be commended. It is important that we have the industries behind us and that the furniture manufacturers, importers and suppliers-retailers are fully supportive of this particular voluntary safety standard.

ANSWER.PARA: As I was saying earlier to Senator Walters, the fact is that the Australian Furniture Testing Research and Development Institute, based in Launceston, Tasmania, will have the prime role in carrying out the various tests on the fabrics and foam fillings used in these furnishings. I believe that the expertise of that institute will be such that those who purchase furnishings in Australia over the next several years can be very confident that they will meet the standards that I am about to describe. The tests to be used are: the smouldering cigarette test, which involves assessing combustion when a lighted cigarette is placed on the furniture--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Tate, this is a very long answer.

—Mr President, it is because I have been diverted; but I am about to complete it. I believe that these tests will be carried out in a way which will be greatly beneficial to Australian purchasers of these furnishing products and, therefore, to those who have such furnishings in their homes and offices.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer to his answers to questions on the deterioration in relations between Australia and India following the sale of Australia's Mirage aircraft to Pakistan. These answers have not been at all satisfactory. I ask: first, is it not the case that, contrary to the Minister's assurance that the supply date was understood, the Indian Foreign Minister wrote to him-after the Minister's visit to India-expressing concern that the delivery dates were apparently not as the Minister had undertaken to him when in India; secondly, did not the Australian High Commission in Delhi propose that ministerial consultations be held immediately following the intended Commonwealth Foreign Ministers' meeting; thirdly, did not the Indian Government then indicate that the timing was inappropriate because of the deterioration in Australia-India bilateral relations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have already answered these questions. There was some suggestion that Australia had breached specific assurances as to the timing of the delivery of these aircraft. There were no such assurances. I have put into the record of this Senate the specific language I used in public press conferences, which make it clear that it was not an assurance being given but simply an expression of our perception as to the likelihood of the delivery date, which is something very different. I can assure Senator Teague, again, as I have previously, that no different language was ever used in private. If there was some misunderstanding of that, then it is not something for which I or the Australian Government can possibly be held responsible. Our position remains absolutely firm on that.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the question of a possible ministerial meeting following a possible meeting of Foreign Ministers on southern Africa and Delhi, I repeat the point that I have previously made to the Senate: no such meeting was ever scheduled or firmly bedded down at any stage. Indeed, the Commonwealth Foreign Ministers' meeting on southern Africa, which would have been the occasion for such a possible meeting, did not in the event go ahead. So there is no foundation for Senator Teague seeking to beat yet more life into a fatally dead old nag of the kind that he is presently trying to beat life into.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade has not answered any of the three questions I put to him: first, did the Indian Foreign Minister write to him; secondly, did the High Commission propose such a meeting; thirdly, did the Indian Government cancel or say that it was inappropriate to have that meeting?

—I cannot recall whether the Indian Foreign Minister specifically wrote to me. There has been a great heap of communications on this subject. It is quite possible that he did. But if he did, he was given a reply in terms of the--
—A copy of the letter?

—I cannot remember. Thousands of people write to me every month on a whole variety of subjects. The particular matter in issue here is as I have described it. No assurance was given. No amount of huffing and puffing and nonsense will turn what was not an assurance into an assurance. The Indians have been told that. You have been told that, so go and bag your head!

—Mr President, on a point of order: I take it that you will follow the procedure which you adopted in relation to Senator Bolkus when he could not contain himself. If this is an example of what we can expect in the future, I think you will have to set new standards of decorum.
—I hardly think it is unparliamentary language, but since the point has been taken I ask Senator Evans to withdraw the comment.
—I withdraw it, Mr President. I suggest that he unbag his head.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I claim to have been misrepresented in a press release put out by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) concerning a supposed version of an interview undertaken in the Kronos program which I believe was broadcast on Friday. In the press release put out by the ABC it was claimed that I spoke of Roman Catholic bishops living in mansions. That in fact was a complete distortion of what I had said, had intended to say and what was in fact broadcast by Kronos the next day. Indeed, the press release was quite a fabrication of my views. Words were attributed to me which I never used. For example, when talking about Anglican archbishops, the interviewer stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the lifestyle that they display from their mansions.
I was offered the bait but I did not take it up. I never used the term `mansions' in my response.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you got a transcript?
—Yes, I have. In response to that particular provocation about Anglican bishops living in mansions I said--
—Was it `manses', not `mansions'?

—It would be wrong to generalise and I would not want to do that. I think it would probably be defamatory, as much as anything. In fact I was avoiding the group smear in which it is said I have indulged. I went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: My own church, and I'm a Roman Catholic, and other more established mainstream churches, there is a danger that the style of life of its chief ordained ministers and the homes in which they reside which have been bestowed on them . . .

Those words were left out of the ABC press release. I was acknowledging there that many of these presbyteries and residences are indeed inherited or bestowed upon ministers by their communities; it is not a question of choice. I continued:
. . . which is not amongst those to whom the gospel was primarily directed. And I think that is a disparity which people do note.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who put out the press release?

—The press release was put out by the ABC. As I say, key words and the middle of a key sentence were left out and other words were attributed to me which in fact fell from the lips of the interviewer. There has been a complete distortion and fabrication of my views. I believe it is a case of very disgraceful journalism. It has brought me into disrepute and it has been extremely embarrassing to me over the last few days. I regard the ABC's distorted publication as defamatory and, as far as I am concerned, I will be seeking an apology and taking other advice as to what action to take. Mr President, I seek leave to--
—Table the transcript.
—Not table but incorporate my letter of this morning and attachments: the ABC press release, the relevant extract from an address and the relevant part of the Kronos interview.
—How long is it?
—It is fairly long but it is very necessary.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The documents read as follows-
Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs
Senator the Hon. Michael Tate
TO BISHOPS AND OTHER LEADERS OF CHRISTIAN CHURCHES IN AUSTRALIA
You will have been as amazed and distressed as I have been at recent distortions of my views as peddled by the Australian Broadcasting Commission.

The press release put out by the ABC (Attachment A) claimed that I spoke of Roman Catholic bishops living in mansions. The fact is I never used such a phrase. The interviewer did, but I didn't take the bait-the ABC has simply made the phrase fall from my lips.

This was part of the desperate attempt by the ABC to get something controversial out of my address the previous week to the Anglican Social Responsibilities Commission (Attachment B)-the last few paragraphs are relevant. The `Kronos' interview implied that I had attacked the Anglican bishops in this matter. It will be apparent that I didn't. In fact, I refused to generalise in a defamatory way because I recognised how unfair that would be.

I enclose a transcript of the Kronos interview as broadcast. This version gives little ground for my supposed attack-I merely pointed to the dangers which are real enough-and, I note that in doing so I acknowledged that many of the residences are bestowed on the clergy, not personally chosen by them. This point was also edited out of the press release version of the interview.

I am trying to get hold of the whole interview tape (unedited) which, I am sure, would confirm my more tempered line. I very much regret the undue furore that has erupted following a very simple observation. May I assure you that the thesis that this is part of a concerted attack by me as a Minister on the church's leadership is utterly without foundation.
Yours sincerely
(Michael Tate)
ATTACHMENT A
RELEVANT PART FROM `MEDIANET'-ABC PRESS RELEASE

Senator Tate, a Roman Catholic layman and an Oxford graduate in Theology, criticised his own Church's perceived hypocrisy in lecturing the government and the community on economic matters while its Bishops lived in mansions.

`There is a danger that the style of life of its chief ministers and the homes in which they reside do put them in a suburb, let alone a lifestyle, which is not adjacent to those to whom the gospel was primarily directed,' he said.
ATTACHMENT B
RELEVANT EXTRACT FROM ADDRESS: SOCIAL RESPONSIBILITY IN THE 1990's

Finally, that Gospel from last week is very pertinent. If you are in the political area, you must have absolute concurrence between what you practise and what you preach. If the Salvoes have credibility in the community, it is because of the absolute concurrence which is perceived between what they say and what they do.
You must not give politicians the opportunity to say, `look what they are saying, and then look at what they are doing''.

Australians have a good nose for hypocrisy and will not readily accept edicts from `on high'-secular or sacred-particularly when they realise there is a great disparity between the professed concerns and the actual lifestyle of those in authority.
ATTACHMENT C
RELEVANT PART OF KRONOS INTERVIEW AS BROADCAST

Austin: Senator Tate in your recent address to the Anglican Church's Social Responsibilities Commission you said `Australians have a good nose for hypocrisy and will not readily accept edicts from on high, secular or sacred. Particularly when they realise there is a great disparity between the professed concerns and the actual lifestyle of those in authority'. You then commended the Salvos, specifically for their obvious consistency but not the Anglicans to whom the address was directed. I take it that you believe that there is an inconsistency between statements from on high by Anglican Archbishops and the lifestyle that they display from their mansions.

Tate: Well, it would be wrong to generalise, and I wouldn't want to do that. I think it would be probably defamatory as much as anything. My own church, and I'm a Roman Catholic, and other more established mainstream churches, there is a danger that the style of life of its chief ordained Ministers and the homes in which they reside which have been bestowed on them, do put them in a suburb, let alone in a lifestyle, which is not amongst those to whom the gospel was primarily directed. And I think that is a disparity which people do note.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation by honourable senators as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable President and members of the Senate assembled in Parliament. This petition of the below citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate that we support the continued cover for all abortions on the Medicare schedule. We oppose any attempt to restrict access to the rebate under Medicare.

Medicare cannot pretend to be a Universal health care system without providing a rebate of a termination of pregnancy. Those who will be hardest hit by proposals to restrict access to items 6469,274 and 275 on the Medicare schedule are poorer and disadvantaged women who will not be able to meet the cost of a non-subsidised abortion.
Your petitioners humbly pray and request that the Senate will vote against any attempt to restrict access to abortion or any abortion-related items on the Medicare schedule.

PETITION.TITLE: United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens shows:
The United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child:
gives wide rights to children in Articles 12 to 16, including the right to privacy and freedom of association;
gives only qualified rights to parents in Article 5;
fails to recognise the prior right of parents to determine the education of their children;
could if ratified by Australia, result in government-assisted rebellion against parents who want to set limits for their children in their children's best interests.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate will:
request the Federal Government not to ratify this potentially damaging Convention.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium: Mining and Export
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That your petitions request that the Australian Government take steps immediately to stop the mining and export of uranium
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme: Erythropoietin
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

Chronic renal failure patients must already endure exhaustive dialysis to just survive. Anaemia, or lack of oxygen-carrying red blood cells that leaves one weak and lethargic, is another symptom some renal patients must also endure. The inability of the kidneys to produce a hormone known as erythropoietin makes transfusions the only viable option for these patients and the transfusion destroys all chances of a transplant due to the increased levels of antibodies.

Now, therefore, your petitioners request that the Senate in Parliament assembled require the Government to make available through an Authority Listing with the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme the recombinant human erythropoietin to those chronic renal failure patients suffering from anaemia.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecommunications: Future Charges
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

The petition of the undersigned shows that there is widespread community concern over the introduction of competition into Australia's telecommunications industry, and that ordinary consumers may be faced with higher prices and reduced services as a result. In particular, we are concerned about the impact on the affordability of telephone services for low income earners and rural consumers.
The petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should introduce legislation to:
(a) protect ordinary consumers from increasing prices and decreasing service and to ensure that the telephone remains an affordable utility
(b) clearly define community service obligations of all telecommunications providers

(c) ensure that, regardless of the structural arrangements, a strong and viable government telecommunications carrier is maintained and continues to provide a universal, affordable service to all Australians.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

DEBATE.TITLE: GUIDE TO THE ASSESSMENT OF RATES OF VETERANS' PENSIONS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, 10 sitting days after today, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That-
(a) the instrument dated 5 November 1990 revoking the previous Guide to the Assessment of Rates of Veterans' Pensions; and

(b) the Guide to the Assessment of Rates of Veterans' Pensions, made under section 29 of the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986, approved by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs on 6 November 1990, and laid before the Senate on 7 November 1990, be disallowed.
I seek leave to make a short statement.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The reason I have given notice of this motion on behalf of the Opposition is to give the Government the maximum time possible to consult with the veterans' community about a change to the calculations of impairment for war disability. Currently veterans are assessed both on their medical impairment and on their lifestyle impairment. Mr President, as you would be aware, the veterans' community campaigned long and hard to get rid of a lifestyle report which was complex, long and difficult for elderly people to complete. In June the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys) announced that that would be abolished and since then the Department of Veterans' Affairs has operated without that lifestyle report. The Government has now introduced instruments which will get rid of the Guide to the Assessment of Rates of Veterans' Pensions 2 and introduce GARP 3, but in doing so it has not taken into account lifestyle effects as a result of medical impairment.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition believes that it is very important for the Government to have proper and meaningful consultations with the veterans' community to see that this, although administratively efficient, should not be done at the expense of a fair go for veterans. There is also concern that GARP 3 might be inconsistent with the Veterans' Entitlements Act. The time made available by the Opposition giving extended notice will enable some of these matters to be taken into account, and will enable the Government to look at alternative ways whereby lifestyle impacts can be factored into the assessment. The Opposition does not wish to delay unnecessarily the efficiency of the administration of the Department of Veterans' Affairs, but it should be right, not just speedy. In giving 10 sitting days notice today, I warn the Government that there is an urgent need to review all those things hand in hand and cooperatively with the veterans' community.

The report before the Senate is the annual report for our international airline, Qantas Airways Ltd, for the 1989-90 financial year. The report documents the very strong growth in Australian tourism that has occurred under the Hawke Government since 1983.

It is very illuminating to look at the numbers of passengers carried by our international carrier, Qantas Airways Ltd. One sees that in 1983, when this Government first came to office, only 2.1 million persons were carried by Qantas. In the year that we are looking at, 1989-90, for which we have the annual report, that number has doubled in just seven years to 4.2 million passengers.

However, the report has some unpleasant news. In comparison with 1988-89, 1989-90 shows a dramatic slump in Qantas revenues and a consequent turnaround in Qantas's position, from a profit the previous year to a loss in the current year of record. In 1988-89, Qantas turned in an operating profit-that is, excluding external and extraneous items such as the sale of aircraft-of $177.2m. In the financial year just ended, Qantas has recorded an operating loss of $125m. So there has been a big turnaround for the worse in the accounts of Qantas.

The annual report documents that a major cause of that turnaround in revenues and in the operating result was the impact of the domestic pilots dispute that began in August last year and extended through into early 1990. It is estimated by Qantas that the pilots strike, even though it was in respect of domestic airlines, affected Qantas profits to the extent of $165m-an enormous sum of money. The strike certainly hit demand for travel to Australia in important markets such as Japan, the United States of America and West Germany.

The current report shows that Qantas is rationalising its routes. It is striking to look at where Qantas now flies to in continental Europe. In this financial year, Qantas has ceased flying to Amsterdam and Athens and it is also terminating services to Bahrain in the current year. It now flies only to Manchester, London, Frankfurt and Rome in Europe.

As Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, I am rather concerned to read in the annual report that Qantas has terminated its services to India. India was a focus of a recent inquiry by the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. It is now the case that our national flag carrier no longer services the second most populous country in the world-a country which early in the next century is set to have the largest population in the world. India has a large potential urban middle class market that I believe can be tapped eventually-not in the short term-for international travel. I am very concerned that that trend has been recorded in this annual report.

I had the opportunity of speaking at a seminar in Melbourne last month on the question of our relations with South Asia and India in particular. At the time the seminar was being held, Qantas was cutting out its flights to Bombay. So, the very week that members of the university and business communities in Melbourne were trying to foster better relations between Australia and India, Qantas was in fact removing its services to Bombay.

As a resident of South Australia, I think Qantas should be doing more to service the smaller capital cities in Australia, particularly Brisbane, Perth and Adelaide where there are not yet enough direct international flights by Qantas to international capitals. It is not satisfactory for people living in those States to have to travel via Sydney and Melbourne airports. Travellers suffer the congestion, holdups and delays caused at those airports, which can add up to half a day to international journeys.

I certainly welcome the long overdue move by Qantas this year to initiate direct flights from Tokyo to Adelaide. I also welcome the doubling of direct non-stop flights from Adelaide to Auckland in New Zealand, which again is a long overdue move. I certainly welcome Qantas's extra connections through Singapore to Bangkok in the current year.
