It might give BASI a real lift if it had an increase in the amount of inquiries from the general public about what it does. There is no difficulty at all in people approaching the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation directly if they want advice about particular incidents. In fact, I would recommend it. The person who rang me at home at one o'clock in the morning about three months ago in relation to what that person thought was a near miss near Sydney Airport would have been far better off going to the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation instead of waking me up at one o'clock in the morning. The more I think about it, the more I think it is a great idea.

SPEECH.PARA: We have an officer from the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation present and I have asked for him to be brought in now, so I will get some more detailed information about the avenues that are available to the public.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the other direction, I also ask the Minister whether the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation could publish at regular intervals in a public forum the sort of information which domestic aviation consumers need to know in order to make informed choices.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure that it would produce publications. I am not personally familiar with them for the simple reason that I of course receive the detailed reports on the investigations as they occur. A document called the Aviation Safety Digest used to be published, and I remember it well. It published fulsome and horrific details of why aircraft crashed: from memory, in most cases accidents were directly attributable to pilot error. The reason I remember the Aviation Safety Digest is that charter companies operating in the Northern Territory for some strange reason insisted on sticking the publication in the pockets of the aircraft on which I regularly flew. So I could read about the latest disaster as the plane was taking off from the airport. I do not know what has happened to John Pike. I have no doubt that BASI publishes newsletters and information for the industry which I am sure would be just as readily available to the public. I will get a detailed response for Senator Kernot as to what it does publish.

—I think it is important that this information is published in industry publications, but they are not widely read by members of the flying public. I would like to see them appear somewhere in readable form. I am not asking for all the gory details; I am merely asking for a list so that people know how many incidents pertain to particular airlines and that sort of thing, so that they can make up their own minds.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly would not want to see BASI indulge in unnecessary publication just in case somebody might read it. The reason why in an Estimates committee hearing I am cautious about giving that commitment is that the Government, as Senator Kernot knows full well, has been belted around the ears to a great extent recently about the pernicious practices of the Department of Social Security in putting pot-plants in its offices and sending out letters to social security recipients. So I would certainly be reluctant to give a blanket guarantee that BASI should churn out 10 million copies of a regular list on the chance that someone may pick it up and read it.

SPEECH.PARA: I inform Senator Kernot that John Pike has left. I have been passed a note which suggests that I invite the honourable senator to visit facilities at BASI for a detailed briefing. What a wonderful suggestion. I was going to suggest to the honourable senator at the conclusion of these questions, as a matter of fact, that I think she would find it more than useful if she paid BASI a visit here in Canberra. I am sure she would find it as instructive as I did. If the honourable senator would like to contact my office, I would be happy to facilitate the visit for her.

TALK.START.PARA: -I thank the Minister but I am also anxious to get some things on the public record-it is not just a matter of looking over the facilities. As that particular gentleman is not here, I shall ask another question. When we were debating migration regulations the matter of foreign pilots was discussed. I understand that they have had exemptions granted by the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) in such matters as morse code endorsements and have had the opportunity to have oral instead of written examinations. My question is: were these exemptions cost cutting measures or is there another explanation?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I can say categorically that in terms of endorsement there were no special concessions made to overseas nationals flying on Australian licences. The testing procedures that were applied to overseas nationals are consistent with those that apply to anyone else. I can certainly assert that because this matter was canvassed at length, and it will be contained in the Hansard records of the Select Committee on Certain Aspects of the Airline Pilots Dispute.

SPEECH.PARA: In respect of morse code endorsement, I have not flown in a Tiger Moth lately but I have not actually seen a morse code key in the cockpits of any of the aircraft that I have flown in recently, so I cannot answer that specific question, except to say that if there is an exemption made for foreign nationals from sending in morse then that same exemption will apply to Australian nationals. But simply to reiterate, I can assure Senator Kernot that, in respect of endorsement for an Australian licence to fly domestic aircraft in Australia, no special concessions or arrangements were made in respect of foreign nationals flying in Australia.

However, I just conclude by saying-and this is where some of the confusion was caused during the Select Committee, as I said earlier-that the CAA is engaged in an ongoing and continuing process of removing unnecessary paperwork and unnecessary regulations that we have simply grown up with over the last half century for no good reason other than that we were doing it the year before.

TALK.START.PARA: -I thank the Minister for that answer. My last question is as follows: would the Minister care to comment on the speculation that pilots from overseas countries are instructed not to give announcements on the intercom in flight?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —As a guide to Senator Kernot, I say that, as a general rule of thumb that I have adopted here, it would be useful to discount completely anything that Senator MacGibbon said about aviation at all. I have found that that is a fairly reliable rule of thumb. The assertion just repeated by Senator Kernot-and I found it astonishing at the time-was in fact made by Senator MacGibbon. That is where it came from. Senator MacGibbon asserted in here that American pilots were forbidden from making public announcements over the PA system of the aircraft. As I said when he raised it at the time, I had just two days before flown to Canberra for the sittings and as we left Darwin in an Ansett 767 a voice came onto the intercom which said, `Good afternoon, this is your captain speaking. We are passing through 20,000 feet at this time', et cetera. If that bloke was an Australian, he needed six months of intensive speech therapy with Paul Hogan because he sounded awfully like an American national to me. The fact is that that assertion is absolute, categorical rubbish. I do not know where Senator MacGibbon dragged it up from.
—He made it up.

—He made it up rather than dragged it up, as Senator Faulkner suggests. It is simply not true, as anyone who flies at all regularly with either Ansett or Australian would well know. What happens on flights these days is what has always happened, and that is that the announcements that are made over the PA are made alternately, usually, by either the captain or the first officer of the aircraft, depending on which leg one is on, the particular day or perhaps even the inclination of the pilots in the cockpit at the time.

SPEECH.PARA: I have to say, however, without casting any aspersions on Australian pilots, that there is no question at all that the public relations skills of American pilots in particular are considerable in that the American pilots whom I have flown with recently seem to take considerable pains over being friendly and addressing the passengers and providing useful information-as of course many of the Australian pilots do too, some more than others, depending on who one flies with.

TALK.START.PARA: —They disturb your sleep.

—Actually they do not. I recall during the pilots dispute, in respect of the introduction of the A320 aircraft, the new Skystar aircraft-which is totally computer controlled, and one of which flew into the ground at the Paris airport because the pilots on board had turned off all of the computer equipment that controlled the safety of the aircraft-what I think was a CAA joke. It was said that the latest safety measure that had been introduced on board these new aircraft was a Doberman pinscher, which was installed in the cockpit, the pilot's job being to feed the Doberman pinscher and the Doberman pinscher's job being to bite the pilot if he touched the controls. I do not think that story was true but there is no question at all that generally speaking these days the safety aspects of aviation in Australia are to a considerable degree safer now, particularly as a result of the enhanced technology that is available on the new designs of aircraft. They are safer now than they have ever been.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: -I feel compelled to dissociate myself from the suggestion by Senator Collins that I got that idea from Senator MacGibbon. Senator MacGibbon is well known for going around Queensland predicting the demise of the Australian Democrats as well and ignoring the fact that it doubled its vote at the last election. I certainly do not rely on Senator MacGibbon as a source for my information. I have been taking my own survey because, like Senator Collins, I do a lot of flying in this job. When the captain does not speak, I ask on my way out what the nationality of the pilot is. I have been compiling my own statistics and I really feel that, since there was a lot of public comment about whether this was happening or not, there has been an increased incidence of Australian first officers making announcements in comparison with captains from overseas countries.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to make it clear that I did not rely on Senator MacGibbon. I am very interested in this. One can usually tell the nationality of the pilot by the quality of the landing. I just wanted to make that point quite clear.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —The only other time I have ever heard this matter raised in the Senate was when Senator MacGibbon spoke about it. Frankly, I have not heard it asserted until now by anyone else. All I can say again categorically is that it is absolute rot. I would suggest, with respect, to Senator Kernot that simply keeping a log of what American pilots were on board the aircraft on which she flies, and whether the first officers speaks, is not a particularly accurate way--
—It is better than nothing, Minister.

—Frankly, I do not actually see the relevance of the question. It does not impinge on whether the captain talks to the passengers, nor does it impinge on the safety of the aircraft. In relation to some of the incidents that I have been involved in over the years, such as landing in bad weather at bad airports, I am grateful that the captain did not talk to me. I have just been given an invaluable piece of information, which I did not know. I quote:

SPEECH.PARA: The captain does not always speak. He would normally only do so if the copilot was flying the A/C.

I assume `A/C' stands for `aircraft'. That is the answer. From my own experience, with a similar anecdotal story, on the flights that I take I regularly hear messages to the cabin from pilots who are unmistakably American.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —It may well be, following Senator MacGibbon raising that matter in this House, that the airlines have reinstructed their pilots differently. Senator MacGibbon has been maligned by the Minister. No-one in this chamber is more personally aware and capable when it comes to matters of flying, aircraft and that sort of thing. As a pilot, Senator MacGibbon has made a personal study of these matters.

SPEECH.PARA: That is by way of preamble to the question I want to raise, Mr Temporary Chairman. In accordance with the earlier ruling made by the Chairman of Committees, I refer to my reservation to program 5.6 on the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority. As the Minister surmised earlier on, I do criticise the length of time it has taken to implement action to reform the waterfront industry. It has been a long time. Time has been ticking away for the Minister; his whole career depends on it.

I want to return to the Cairns waterfront. Is the month trial period up yet? Is the Minister satisfied with the way this aspect of waterfront reform has been dealt with, bearing in mind that the Cairns port is the first regional port to be dealt with and may well be a precedent for other regional ports throughout Australia? Is the Minister happy with the way the whole process has been carried out at Cairns? When does he expect to get some finality in respect of this matter?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —The great difficulty with getting a resolution in respect of Cairns was caused by the very feature of the negotiation to which Senator Macdonald has alluded-that is, rightly or wrongly, it has been seen by many people on both sides of the fence as a precedent. The significant delays in getting a resolution to this issue have not been entirely one-sided. As Tas Bull pointed out to me with some vehemence and a great deal of validity some time ago, it is interesting that this port, which has a long history of being a busy port, has suffered a massive decline in the business it once used to do. I might say that ports around Australia and, in fact, around the world tend to wax and wane. The difficulty with Cairns, as Tas pointed out to me, is that all the emphasis has constantly been directed entirely at the waterside workers in the port, to the exclusion of all other workers.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no question that with the original attitude of the then port authority, that was very much the case. That authority, for whatever reason, had a positive antipathy towards that union and predicated all its suggestions for achieving some sort of resolution to the problems in Cairns on removing the union from the port. That was never a viable approach. I had no difficulty at all in asserting that to the new authority when I met with it. But this significantly impeded any progress. With great respect, an approach by which one party is determined to achieve a solution which would remove from the port the organisation with which it is negotiating and which, rightly or wrongly currently represents the workers, is doomed to failure.

Unfortunately that delayed proceedings. There have been some recent changes in the management of Northern Shipping and Stevedoring Pty Ltd that operates in the Port of Cairns, which I hope will not delay the proceedings any longer. However, there has been a significant amount of activity in relation to Cairns port in recent times. Last week the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority convened a series of meetings with all parties involved in Cairns and that process is now being assessed. There will be further discussions with the parties this week. Failing any resolution of the problem this week by agreement, the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority has agreed to make-and I was advised of this by Peter Evans on Friday last week-a determination or recommendations as to the basis on which the problem in Cairns must be resolved and by which the work force has to be reduced.

I expect to have that in my hands this week. But, hopefully, the parties with which discussions are now being held will reach some accommodation themselves to resolve the difficulty. I am aware of at least half a dozen proposals around but all of them have proved to be deficient in one area or another. It has now got to the point where if the negotiation that is currently under way fails, the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority, as I have said, will make a determination or recommendation to me about what should happen at Cairns, and that will be implemented.

TALK.START.PARA: —The reason people in the position of the Cairns Port Authority are concerned about the Waterside Workers Federation is that is where all the rorts have stemmed from over the years that the Minister has recognised.
—It is your attitude that contributes to a failure to solve the problem, because that is not correct.

—I thought that was the Minister's attitude, too. It was certainly the attitude of the Inter-State Commission report. Unfortunately, I do not have the document with me-it is in my office-but did it not recommend that the Waterside Workers Federation retire from the Cairns port? One could hardly blame the Cairns Port Authority for trying to implement that recommendation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Macdonald's ignorance of what the Inter-State Commission report actually says is so breathtaking that all I can suggest to him, with great respect, is that if he has a genuine interest in this area, he should go back and read the report for the first time. The Inter-State Commission report did not make a specific recommendation that the Waterside Workers Federation be removed from the Port of Cairns at all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I was talking about the recommendation of the Inter-State Commission (ISC) report in respect of union coverage in small ports. That recommendation was to the effect that the Waterside Workers Federation (WWF) should-voluntarily, I might add-withdraw its union coverage from small ports. That was one of only two recommendations in the entire ISC report that the Government did not accept. The Government's waterfront reform program is based in its entirety on the recommendations of the Inter-State Commission report.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Macdonald made an observation that one of the reasons why the antipathy was directed towards the WWF in the port of Cairns by the Cairns Port Authority board was that the WWF had caused all the problems and that that was exactly why the Inter-State Commission had recommended that it should withdraw its coverage from Cairns. Even scant reference to the ISC's report indicates that that is not the case at all. The recommendation that the ISC did make in respect of small ports goes to the very heart of why the Government did not see the recommendation, as industrially naive as I must say it was, for the WWF to voluntarily withdraw its coverage from all of the small ports around Australia-it would have been an interesting exercise in defining what a small port was, apart from anything else-as part of the in-principle agreement (IPA). It had nothing whatever to do with the alleged sins of the WWF. In fact, page 222 of the Inter-State Commission report referred to the desirability of having integrated port work forces. It had nothing whatever to do with any particular criticism of the WWF as a union, as asserted by Senator Macdonald. It stated:

The concept of an integrated workforce appears particularly relevant to smaller ports, where it is difficult to maintain a balanced workload for both the port authority workforce and the stevedoring workforce. Combination of these two workforces would facilitate much more efficient utilisation of labour and thus improve the longer term viability of the port.

Indeed, it would. The reason that the Government did not see the need to adopt that recommendation is that the union movement has done that. The situation currently is-certainly at the time the data for this report was collected it was not apparent, but it is now-that the maritime union movement is engaged in a major process of amalgamation of unions which will result in the formation of a single federation of maritime unions representing the majority of the unions that currently represent workers on the waterfront and, indeed, in shipping and in ports. Negotiations are well advanced in that regard. Negotiations between the Seamen's Union of Australia and the WWF have been going on for some years. Not only have those negotiations been expedited; the Australian Council of Trade Unions has formally moved in recent times to make a section 118 application to the Industrial Relations Commission for such an amalgamation to go ahead.

Of course, at the same time the inevitable will happen-rationalisation of the awards, which the Inter-State Commission also talked about as a prerequisite to having an effective integrated work force concept in ports. I made some criticism of that particular Inter-State Commission recommendation at the time as being industrially naive, and I do not withdraw from that. There would be the prospect of negotiating an in-principle agreement with, as part of the conditions upon which that agreement was negotiated, the voluntary removal of union coverage from a whole host of small ports around Australia where the union has had that coverage since the year dot. Expecting to have been able to successfully negotiate the IPA, as happened, with that as a prerequisite would have placed a formidable barrier in the front of the negotiation of that in-principle agreement-in fact, it would have prevented its negotiation.

But that is not the relevant issue, as I said before. The relevant issue is that the recommendation of the Inter-State Commission for the WWF voluntarily to withdraw coverage from all small ports around Australia had nothing whatever to do with any suggestions about it causing all the trouble in small ports; it had to do with the sensible suggestion of the Inter-State Commission to establish integrated port work forces in smaller ports and is a process which the union movement itself is now advancing with some considerable effort in regard to both the rationalisation of the awards and the amalgamation of all maritime unions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am surprised-and I learn every day-to hear the explanation of the Minister. Certainly the Inter-State Commission report recommended:

SPEECH.PARA: The Waterside Workers Federation should enter into in-principle agreement for withdrawal of its coverage in ports where integrated workforces are established.

I understood the reason for that to be that the Waterside Workers Federation would only work on certain projects on the waterfront. In the Cairns instance in particular, the idea was to have an integrated work force which would do some stevedoring work, some gardening work and possibly some chauffeuring work-all different sorts of manual work on the waterfronts. The Waterside Workers Federation would not allow its members to do that; it wanted its members to deal with their own particular trades. That has been one of the causes of the high costs of operating the waterfront.

I understand that the Australian Workers Union (AWU), which is a very potent force in Queensland Labor politics, was quite happy to take over the whole integrated work force at the Cairns Port Authority. I understand that the Waterside Workers Federation, naturally, did not want to be pushed out, but the AWU was quite happy to take over this integrated work force at the Cairns Port Authority. It seemed to all involved, including the Inter-State Commission, that that was the way to go.

It is rather surprising to me that the Government has accepted, as I understand the Minister to say, all of the recommendations bar two, and this is one of them. I wonder whether that has anything to do with the connections between the Waterside Workers Federation and the Australian Council of Trade Unions, with its influence on the Government. Has the Government been pressured into doing something in relation to the Cairns Port Authority which, as the Minister acknowledges, will be seen by many as a precedent for all of the smaller and regional ports around the country? It would seem surprising to me that the Government should accept all bar two recommendations, of which this is one-one which has some influence in dealing with some of its mates in the Waterside Workers Federation.

Certainly at the moment the parties in Cairns are looking at another proposal but I understand from most of the parties that that is a second choice that they have been more or less forced into by reason of the fact that the recommendation made by the Inter-State Commission has not been accepted by the Government. I suspect that they are the facts of the matter and the reason many people see the reform of the waterfront as a Claytons reform in many respects which does not go to the root of the problem which the Inter-State Commission identified. In the same vein, I ask the Minister when the redundancies are expected to take effect in the Cairns Port area and how those redundancy payments are to be made and funded.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —A little knowledge certainly is a dangerous thing. As I have just explained, I find Senator Macdonald's assertions about special relationships or connections between the Australian Labor Party (ALP) and the Waterside Workers Federation of Australia (WWF) as opposed to the Australian Workers Union (AWU) not only startling in their ignorance, but also amusing from a personal point of view. I have served on the national executive of the Australian Labor Party for five years and, at most meetings, I sat alongside my factional colleague and good friend Errol Hodder, who is the General Secretary of the Australian Workers Union. I find it extremely amusing to be accused of having some special arrangement with Tas Bull and the waterside, as opposed to the AWU; nevertheless, if Senator Macdonald--
—A lot of people in Cairns don't think it is nonsense.

—It was just a nonsensical assertion, with respect; it was absolute nonsense. I accused the Inter-State Commission of being industrially naive. Senator Macdonald would have to join that club with a vengeance. To say that the AWU was happy at the prospect of taking over the membership of the WWF, as if this were some sort of commendation or some surprising concession on the part of the AWU, is breathtaking. Of course the AWU would be delighted to have the WWF walk into the negotiating room for the in-principle agreements and voluntarily, before the negotiations had even begun, relinquish the union coverage it has had for half a century or longer over members scattered in small ports across Australia. To not expect the AWU to be delighted with that arrangement is breathtaking. I have no doubt that Errol Hodder, being the consummate union leader that he is, would be more than delighted to take over union membership of every other union in the country if such an opportunity presented itself.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason the Government did not proceed to adopt the two recommendations-one relating to union coverage and the other relating to stand-down provisions-was that in the first instance it was, correctly, in the view of the Government, industrially naive to believe that the WWF would voluntarily relinquish such coverage and, secondly, it was unnecessary in any case because a major reform movement was under way, of which we were well aware, within the union movement itself to provide the very rationalisation that the Inter-State Commission was seeking that can apply to the small ports.

For the advice of Senator Macdonald, there is no reluctance on the part of the stevedoring work force in Cairns to perform other duties; that is not the difficulty at all. Not only have the workers communicated this fact to the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority, or whoever else cared to listen to them, but they have personally communicated it to me in meetings that I have had with them in Cairns. They have no objection whatever to working in the port authority, doing all the tasks to which Senator Macdonald referred. What they did object to-I think understandably enough-was the proposition that their union, as a union, should be removed from the port. Those meetings are continuing this week to see whether there can be some resolution by agreement. If not, then the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority will move to make recommendations about the arrangements that should operate in Cairns, even if that is only on an interim basis.

As the Minister, I will be perfectly happy to accept an interim solution, pending the resolution through the Industrial Relations Commission-which is where it will be determined in the end-of the question of union coverage and award restructuring which the Commission will oversight. That will occur some time this week. If that is finally what happens-if it cannot be resolved amicably or by discussion-as soon as that resolution is implemented, the excess workers will be removed as quickly as possible from the port of Cairns.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins) says the excess workers will be removed as quickly as possible. Is there a timetable for their removal? Can the Minister also confirm what I thought he said, that is, that the Waterside Workers Federation members who will continue to be employed at the Cairns port will take on any employment directed to them-whether there are ships in port or not, whether it is relating directly to the waterfront or only indirectly-and do whatever is asked of them by their employers?

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, earlier today you ruled me out of order when I sought to discuss the aerodrome local ownership plan (ALOP). SPEECH.PARA: I would like to ask a couple of questions on section 1.7, the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA). The Minister might remember that during Estimates committee hearings I asked what measures CAA takes to make sure that pilots adhere to the strict conditions of abstinence from drinking alcohol so many hours before flying. What led me to asking this question again was a report in the New York Times of 27 October 1990, which someone posted to me. It pointed out that three American pilots from Northwest Airlines Inc. were suspended and, in fact, imprisoned for flying when drunk, with various amounts of alcohol in their blood. At the trial the pilots argued that because the 40-minute flight was uneventful the alcohol they drank did not make them incapable of flying. That was a peculiar defence.

I cannot give the honourable senator an undertaking-as she is seeking-that Telecom will do this, because I am not the Minister responsible for Telecom; Mr Beazley is.

What I will do, as is proper for me to do as his representative in this chamber, is place Senator Newman's suggestion before the Minister for Transport and Communications and provide honourable senators with Mr Beazley's response when it is available to me. That applies to the second part of Senator Newman's question as well as the first.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the Minister answered the second part of my question he lent exclusively on the question of obscenity, which was not what I raised. I drew his attention to the fact that he is a Minister in a government which claims not to believe in the exploitation of women. There can be no doubt that these services exploit, degrade and use women. If the Government is to be consistent with what it claims is its policy, how is it that it allows this? The Minister is a Minister in a government that claims it does not support the exploitation of women, yet it is overseeing a public authority which is allowing that to happen. It is contracting; if you like, it is living off the earnings of immoral income. It is no good for the Minister to hide behind whether it is obscene, whether Minister Beazley has a policy on obscenity or whether it is between consenting adults. I raised a different matter altogether with him, but he would not come to grips with that. Does the Government see these guidelines as being consistent with its apparent policy on the exploitation of women?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —When I said that this debate was on very familiar ground, I meant it. What we are back to-and we have been over it at considerable length in the short time I have been a member of this chamber-is whether this material itself is exploitative of women and degrades them. A whole range of opinion has been expressed in this Parliament on that question.
—What is your view?

—Senator Kemp was not here at the time I spoke about this. I would like to restrict, if I could, the time of a very busy chamber to the Estimates rather than to recanvassing for the sole benefit of Senator Kemp hours of tedious debate on that question.
—No, just give us a straight answer.

—That is a straight answer. There is an excellent parliamentary database in this Parliament, which Senator Kemp probably never uses and probably does not know how to access. I suggest that Senator Kemp type in his computer code, get the computer to recognise him, as it has to with Discovery--
—A very weak response.

—Not at all. I suggest Senator Kemp type in my name and then type in as a supplementary question `X-rated videos', and he will get printed out on his printer everything I have said about the subject at length. I do not propose to canvass the entire substantive debate again for the personal edification of Senator Kemp.
—But that was before you were a Minister.
—Order!

—Once again the injunction of the person who previously occupied the Chair is being totally ignored by honourable senators opposite. I say through you, Mr Chairman, in direct response to that interjection-and maybe we can short-circuit this debate-that my views on the substantive issue of this material are the same now as they were then. Perhaps that will answer the question for the honourable senator when he digs these things out.

SPEECH.PARA: I assure Senator Kemp that the computers in this Parliament, which are sadly underutilised by the senators and members who have access to them, are extremely efficient. Within 10 minutes Senator Kemp can read everything he ever wanted to hear from me about X-rated videos. I have not changed those views, in response to Senator Baume's quite proper question.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for his diatribe but I asked him a specific question about this Telecom service. He did not address himself to it at all.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —With respect-and I answer this for the third and last time-Senator Newman has asked me whether I can give an undertaking that Telecom will comply with certain requests from her. In fact, I think this is the fourth time. I cannot give such an undertaking because I am not the Minister responsible. So far as the Telecom guidelines are concerned, I am happy to express a personal view, which is that the two paragraphs I have just read from the guidelines encapsulate very largely my view.
—No, the Government's view on women.

—For the fifth time I will say again-I do not know why; in fact, I do know why-that if Senator Newman wants to engage the Committee in this sort of tedious repetition I am happy to get up six, seven, eight or 10 times. I cannot be more precise than I was the first time. I will refer both parts of Senator Newman's question to the responsible Minister. When I have a response from the responsible Minister I will advise the Committee.
—I am a bit confused about this. The Minister referred to two paragraphs. He previously quoted two paragraphs from Janet Strickland which dealt with the 0055--
—No, they are the wrong two paragraphs, Senator.
—What are the two paragraphs?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I gave two quotes. I quoted one paragraph from Janet Strickland stating her views on censorship.
—That adults can see and hear what they like.

—Again, despite the non-stop interjections from Senator Walters, I quoted two paragraphs from the guidelines that are contained in Attachment 2 to the additional information received by the Senate Committee which relate to the need for the basic right of an adult to see and read what he wants to see and read but to be protected from unsolicited material.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not an issue here.
—It was with Senator Newman.

—It is not an issue because adults are simply not free to read and view a whole range of material. In short, adults are not free to read or view anything that is not published. The question really boils down to whether Telecom Australia has the approval of the Government to act as publisher of this material. If we are being fair dinkum about it, that is the question. I ask the Minister to put that question to the board of Telecom and to ask whether it approves of the classification of guidelines which is contained in Attachment 3 to the answers that were given to me.

SPEECH.PARA: Does the board of management agree that this material should be published over its networks? Does the board of Telecom agree that this public instrumentality should be used as a publisher of this material? The question that needs to be raised with the Minister, Mr Beazley, is whether he believes that the services of Telecom should be used to publish this material on a commercial basis, as it is. I leave aside for a moment the question of private discussions between individual subscribers.

The reason that I raised the questions is that it is clear to me from the material that is provided to me by Telecom that the board of directors have not been involved in this. I may not be reading everything correctly but that seems to me to be the case.

It appears to me that the board of Telesoft Communications Pty Ltd, which is not the board of Telecom, has been making the decisions. If we want, we can have our differences of opinion on various issues, but we want to get clear what Telecom's views are because a precedent is being established here and if that precedent is allowed to go through, it will be inconsistent with the statements that have been made by the current Minister, Mr Beazley, in respect at least of pay television.

Finally, on Discovery, I want to ask one more question which the Minister can take on notice if he wishes: does condition 5.5 relate to what a service provider can place on the Discovery database or does it bind only the consumer? Who is the consumer in this case? Is it the subscriber, is it the service provider, or is it both? Is it possible for Telecom to direct that service providers not include material that is offensive or abusive or of an indecent, obscene or menacing character?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have already, in response to Senator Newman, answered one part of Senator Harradine's question. As he quite correctly says, it is a matter for the responsible Minister to put the Government's position. The information that I am given, and which I have previously given, is that it appears that the board of Telecom Australia has not had an involvement in this matter. Senator Harradine's assumption appears to be correct. I will raise that question with the responsible Minister, and I repeat the undertaking that I will discuss with Minister Beazley the concerns that have been raised by honourable senators in this debate and put to him whether it is appropriate for the board of Telecom to be involved. On the advice I am given, apparently Senator Harradine's assumption is correct and the board has not been involved. Secondly, I will ask Mr Beazley, as I have already given an undertaking to do, what the Government's position is on these guidelines.

SPEECH.PARA: In response to the last question that Senator Harradine asked-which I can answer now, but Senator Harradine will probably seek some further documented information on this, which no doubt will be made available to him-the contract for the customer is a standard contract because it applies to all of the customers of the service, but the contracts between the company and the service providers vary from service to service. The answer to Senator Harradine's question is that I am advised those contracts contain a clause in similar terms to condition 5.5 in respect of Customs which prohibits the service providers from providing this kind of material and can be enforced if that provision is breached.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Hill

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. There is concern on this side of the chamber about an apparent ruling or lack of a ruling given by the Chair prior to your return to the chair on this occasion. The Minister apparently said to those on this side of the chamber that they should `piss off'. I would have thought that that was clearly unparliamentary and that he would have been asked to withdraw and, hopefully, apologise. It seems that it was either decided by the Chair that it was not unparliamentary, which is vitally important if it is to be used as a precedent in the Senate that such language is not unparliamentary or, alternatively-this is the confusion-that the Chair failed to rule at all. I wonder whether, in your position as Chairman of Committees, you could rule on this matter.

INTERJECT.PARA: With respect, I think the sensible way of dealing with this matter, whether it is the orderly way or not, is to indicate that such language is clearly unparliamentary. The Minister might like to consider voluntarily withdrawing and apologising on this occasion. It is clearly offensive language and clearly offended my colleagues. It is not the first time in the last few days that Ministers have been swearing across the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —Isn't it?

—I am saying that the Minister has, as have his colleagues. This chamber cannot work effectively without a certain degree of dignity. The Government seems to be under extreme stress at the moment, but the behaviour of Ministers is falling far short of the very reasonable standards that we expect. Mr Chairman, I ask you to take action to resolve this matter.

—Mr Chairman, on the point of order, there is a third possibility which Senator Hill did not advert to; that is, that the Chair did not hear the expression used by the Minister. If the Minister was not facing the Chair and it was simply an aside made across the chamber, then--
—He was facing the Chair.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Tate

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I be allowed to speak without interruption? I am suggesting that that may be yet another possibility in the unfolding of the events. I was not in the chamber at the time; I was trying to follow it on television. Mr Chairman, you ought to take that into account.

INTERJECT.PARA: The fact is that the matter ought to be regarded as closed. There was some discussion, as I understand it, in relation to the Temporary Chairman's attempt during the ringing of the bells to call for all interjections from all sides to cease; in other words, he tried to deal with a situation of some disorder in the chamber. It is his task as Temporary Chairman of the Committee to preserve order in the chamber as would normally be done by the President in the Senate proper. He tried to discharge that duty, and I believe that the matter ought to be regarded as concluded. As I understand it, under standing order 145, if there were any objection to his dealing with the matter in the way that he did at that stage, then the matter should have been submitted to the Chair in writing and dealt with. It was not, and I think, quite properly, that the matter ought to be regarded as at rest, particularly given the fact that there is an alternative explanation. But even if there were not, the time has passed for that particular matter to be reopened.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I would have to say that I could not be more disappointed in the line that Senator Tate has taken in addressing this matter. It has been dealt with most reasonably by Senator Hill, not in the sense of challenging the Chairman's ruling or anything of that kind, which under standing order 198 would have been done immediately at the time, but merely to get a ruling as to whether or not the words shouted across the chamber-at a time when there was not disorderly conduct on this side of the chamber, but there may have been afterwards, and with understandable reason-are to be regarded in the future as suitable words to be shouted by Ministers at the Opposition. I do not believe that they are. I think it was reasonable for Senator Hill to ask for a ruling. I think it is most regrettable indeed that Senator Tate intervened in the way he did by saying that he was not in the chamber at the time. There could have been nothing aggressive about the way that--
—Were you here?
—I was watching it and listening and I saw exactly what happened.
—I heard it on my television.

—Senator Crichton-Browne came into the chamber just after I did for exactly the same reason. I think it most regrettable that Senator Tate should be pursuing a course which may lead to this chamber having on its record those sorts of words as acceptable language to be used in this place.
—Mr Chairman, I can assist in resolving this matter very easily by doing as I have done for 14 years as a servant of Parliament, that is, withdrawing unreservedly anything which any other senator--
—In that tone of voice?

—Senator Tambling should not be tedious. I can assist by unreservedly withdrawing-if I can be allowed to finish-any comment that I might make that any other senator would find offensive, and I do so unreservedly withdraw it.

SPEECH.PARA: In respect of the difficulty to which Senator Tate alluded, it has to be said in defence of my colleague Senator Aulich that it would have been quite impossible for him to know what anyone had said. I point out to Senator Reid, with great respect, that she was not in the chamber at the time. I found the constant interjections particularly difficult, offensive, and very hard to put up with. They meant that Senator Aulich would not have been in a position to know what anyone had said--

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish.

—It is on again. I was in the process, and happily conceded it, of trying to obtain from the advisers some precise and accurate information in response to questions being asked by Senator Harradine which I personally did not know the answer to. I found it absolutely impossible to hear either what they were saying or what Senator Harradine was saying, because of the non-stop interjections of both Senator Newman and Senator Walters. It did not stop for 10 minutes.

SPEECH.PARA: I find it very difficult. It is one thing to interject constantly during a second reading debate-that is fine-but it is another thing in the committee stage of the Appropriation Bill. The questions are very complex and technical, and it is very frustrating, when trying to provide information which has been hastily scribbled down or spoken to me, to have non-stop and very loud interjections coming from the other side of the chamber to the point where I literally cannot hear what is being said to me.

I have to say that Senator Aulich was absolutely correct in saying that it was very noisy indeed on both sides of the chamber. The position that he took on it was understandable, in my view. In conclusion, I say again that the issue can be resolved very quickly indeed because I unreservedly and unconditionally withdraw.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will take one more speaker on the point of order before making a ruling.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator O'Chee

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I respectfully submit to you a previous ruling made by a President of this Senate on 31 October 1967. It was a ruling of President Sir Alister McMullin. He ruled on a matter that Senator Tate has raised. Senator Hill suggested that either there was a ruling that the words were in order or that there was no ruling at all. Senator Tate then said, quite correctly, that there was a third possibility, which was that the words were not heard by the Chair.

INTERJECT.PARA: Mr Chairman, I submit this paragraph of President Sir Alister McMullin's ruling, which I believe is of relevance and is, of course, no slight at all upon the previous Deputy Chairman. He said:

As a working rule, the Chair will always intervene when unparliamentary language is used. But, as honourable senators know, expressions which may be ruled out of order in Parliament cover a wide range. The Chair is often required to make very quick decisions regarding these expressions. If through circumstances at the time quick decisions cannot be made, or a disorderly expression is used which may not be heard by the Chair but which is recorded in Hansard, I think it serves the dignity of the chamber that the Chair should take the first opportunity of informing the Senate of those expressions which will be disallowed in the future.

On page 161 of Australian Senate Practice by J. R. Odgers it is noted that both the then Leader of the Government, Senator Gorton, and the then Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, Senator Murphy, made statements agreeing with the President's statement. Accordingly, I very humbly submit to you, Mr Chairman, that this is an appropriate opportunity for you to make a ruling to ensure that we do not create an unseemly precedent in this chamber and, even if Senator Tate is correct, it still does not invalidate your ruling that the words in question are unparliamentary.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It seems to me that under normal circumstances the words which have been alleged to have been used would not have been in Hansard because, at that time, a quorum was being called so, technically, the Senate would not be in session and the words would not be recorded.

INTERJECT.PARA: As well as that, there is some doubt whether the words would be recorded in Hansard anyway, because they were interjections, and all interjections are disorderly. Like many other honourable senators, I was not in the chamber at the time, but I was watching the proceedings on television and saw most of what occurred. I will quite categorically say that if those words were said in this chamber they were disorderly-in fact, I would probably call them grossly disorderly. At the time the Temporary Chairman tried to call both sides to order because apparently interjections were coming from both sides. I do not want to indicate whether there were more interjections from one side or the other, but they came from both sides of the chamber. He attempted to call the chamber to order. I am not aware whether he heard the interjections, but Senator Collins has now said that he has withdrawn those words and I think the matter should rest there.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I thank you, Mr Chairman, for the sensible way in which you have dealt with the matter. I think it is important that the record of Hansard now will clearly indicate that those words are disorderly. That satisfies one of our concerns. I also thank the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins) for his unreserved withdrawal, which meets the parliamentary question we raised. I can only say I am disappointed that the Minister was not prepared to go that one step further, which I would have thought accorded to decent behaviour, and apologise to those whom he has offended.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Of course I do offer any apology if it is required. But, frankly, knowing the people as I do, I would not have thought that one was required. I have to say that all of this did occur after the quorum was called when, as far as I was aware, the Senate was not in session.
—Order! I think that while we are still slightly ahead it might be better to move on.

—Mr Chairman, I claim to have been misrepresented. During his explanation Senator Collins said that he responded to continual interjections by Senator Newman and me while he was trying to clarify information he was receiving from the departmental officers. That was definitely not the case. Neither I nor Senator Newman were interjecting when that occurred. It was only when Senator Collins made a rude comment regarding Senator Harradine that Senator Newman and I objected to his comments. It was then that Senator Collins used the offensive language. I want it recorded that neither I nor Senator Newman were interjecting at the time Senator Collins claims we were. It is totally untrue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I raise the matter of the 0055 service, I ask the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins) whether Telecom Australia could answer the item about who the `adult' service providers were on the Discovery service. The response that Telecom gave was not appropriate. Telecom said that there are instances where certain service providers have specific industry applications that are not accessible by general users and that in these cases Telecom has an agreement that their identity remains commercial-in-confidence. That response does not suggest that Telecom has commercial-in-confidence agreements with these people. If it has, there is nothing much we can do about it, but I ask that that be taken on notice. In so far as answers can be given, they should be provided.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason I want to know, and I think the Senate ought to know, is that the officials of Telesoft Communications Pty Ltd-not the board of Telecom- are at present negotiating with some of these service providers to take over the adult Discovery service. If that occurs, there will be no control over the service at all. We ought to be kept informed about what is happening in that area.

I will now turn to the question of 0055 and go to the answers that have been provided to me by Telecom in regard to 0055. There have been some answers given, but there are some which need clarification. First, I will deal with the question of the appointment of Janet Strickland. In response to people who have asked about this question, Telecom has written letters over the signature of Mr S.M. Fish, Manager External Relations Corporate Secretariat. One letter says that Telecom is currently reviewing its contracts with 0055 service providers and has enlisted the assistance of a respected independent consultant to revise standards relating to 0055 message content and advertising. In question 9, I asked:

When did Telecom first decide to review Telecom's 0055 message content and advertising standards? What specifically gave rise to that decision? Have there been complaints from `adult' service providers about 0055 operational requirements or about any Telecom restrictions on message content? If so, what service providers made the complaints, when were they made and what were the nature of these complaints?
That question has not been adequately answered. I then asked this question:

What amounts have been paid and are budgeted to be paid to Janet Strickland and Associates for the work performed or to be performed on revising standards relating to 0055 message content and advertising? When is this work likely to be completed? What procedures are then to be followed by Telecom and by the Government. Were advertisements placed or tenders called for that consultancy? When was the decision made to appoint Janet Strickland and Associates for this consultancy?
The answers to these questions are totally inadequate, as one will see. The answer to question 10 states:

The contracted sum to be paid by Telecom to Janet Strickland and Associates for preparation of the Discussion Paper and Final Report is confidential. The Discussion Paper was released in June 1990 and the Final Report which contains recommendations will be released in October.

The point is: why is this confidential? Questions about consultancies are often asked in Estimates. Surely the public is entitled to know what consultants are being paid, and what they are being paid to do, by government instrumentalities and authorities such as this. That is what we are all about. It is extraordinary that this is not forthcoming. The response goes on:

The commissioning of Janet Strickland and Associates arose from the extensive experience and skills of its principal, Mrs Janet Strickland, to undertake a review of 0055 services. Mrs Strickland is a founding member of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, a former Chief Commonwealth Film Censor and has acted as a consultant to the Film, Video and Television industries since 1986.
It then states:
The opinion within Telecom was that the calling of tenders would have been unlikely to attract an organisation with a consultant equivalent to the calibre of Mrs Strickland.

I would like to know whether Telecom had regard to the consultancies that Janet Strickland has had in the area. Did they know of her views about these situations and her statements? In the Sydney Morning Herald of 24 June 1986 Mrs Strickland is quoted:

. . . the greater government interference would occur through the appointment to the Film Censorship Board and the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal of people ``with predictably conservative social views and through more restrictive censorship legislation''.
An industry paper called Freeze Frame of 1 April 1987, under the heading `Censorship Under Scrutiny', states:

In what appears to be part of a continuing trend towards conservatism, it is expected that the recommendation of the Joint Parliamentary Committee on censorship matters will be the tightening of theatrical and video ratings, especially the `R' certificate.
The report of the Committee is due to be handed to the government at any time and has prompted swift action by the Film and Video Coalition.

The Coalition, a group of film distributors and exhibitors, television program distributors and video distributors met recently to discuss the common concern. It has established a fighting fund to mount an industry and public awareness campaign aimed at maintaining the present guidelines.

Janet Strickland, chairperson of the Film and Video Coalition and former chief censor, has been working with the Lintas advertising agency to formulate a major campaign, ``to oppose moves by the Joint Parliamentary Committee to tighten guidelines.'' Strickland adds that the guidelines ``have already been amended twice and we see no reason to make further restrictions.''

I could give a number of other quotations on her preconceived views about this question, and here is Telecom appointing her to do a survey of 0055 standard and message content in response to public concern about the material-if we are to believe Telecom-which is being published by Telecom in the interests of sexploit profiteers. I would like to know whether Telecom knew of that publicly expressed attitude of Janet Strickland. Does Telecom realise what is involved in the final report of Janet Strickland in regard to the 0055 service, and particularly what Janet Strickland believes to be material that is grossly offensive?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to the first part of Senator Harradine's question, I am advised that the review was prompted by two things: direct representation from members of the public to Telecom regarding the 0055 service and a court case involving a company called Omnicall in Victoria.

SPEECH.PARA: As to the other detail that Senator Harradine is seeking-that is, whether Telecom had regard to or considered Janet Strickland's previous involvement-personally I do not know whether it did or not, but I will inquire. I must say that I would be amazed if it did not; and I assume that it was, in fact, her background and her considerable and significant involvement in censorship that were directly responsible for Telecom going to her as someone with expertise in this area.

I also point out that a reading of her final report and recommendations shows that it does not set the standards. In fact, it lays out the appropriate mechanism to be used for actually determining them. I am not quite sure whether any of the positions that Janet Strickland has adopted are necessarily relevant to what she has said in this report.

As to the recommendation she has made about setting the process in place that can in fact be used to assess this material, the chapter headed `Who should set the standards?' deals with this, but the actual report in itself does not make judgments about setting the standards.

As to the specific question of whether Telecom had regard to her previous experience, I say again that I think common sense would probably dictate that, considering her reputation and her very public profile as a Commonwealth film censor, no doubt it did.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to follow that point. The Minister referred to chapter 3 in the final report Setting the Standards. This is the crux of the issue, and this is why I raised the issue about Janet Strickland. Recommendation 1 of that chapter says:

SPEECH.PARA: That standards be set for telephone information, message content and advertising.
Recommendation 2 says:

That such standards attempt to give expression to the philosophy that adults should have the maximum freedom to impart and receive information and ideas; that children should not be exposed to messages or advertising which may be harmful to them; and that the public at large should be protected from messages and advertising which, inter alia, is misleading, false or grossly offensive.

Later on the report looks at the question of establishing a committee. It recommends the setting up of a committee of seven members to be appointed under the auspices of Telecom to set standards for telephone information service message content and advertising. But that committee will be bound by that alleged philosophy of Janet Strickland. The recommendation says:

That in setting the Telephone Information Service message content and advertising standards, the Committee seek the widest possible range of views within the community; have regard to standards applying in related areas; and in light of the general statement of objectives contained in Recommendation 2 . . .

In other words, the committee has its hands tied, and it will be tied to what is, in Janet Strickland's view, grossly offensive. She will be on the committee to give advice to that committee as to what is grossly offensive. I turn to the Hansard transcript of 12 December 1984, when Mrs Strickland appeared before the then Senate Select Committee on Video Material. She is quoted as saying:
That is the obscenity test which we tend not to use. We use the indecency test.
Senator Elstob, as he then was, said:
Indecency?
Mrs Strickland said:
Yes. That is that `which is grossly offensive to the reasonable man'.
She went on at page 149:
I think that has to be the answer, that what grossly offends a reasonable person is bestiality, child pornography, incitement to drug abuse, terrorism and sexual violence.

In other words, what is being said here is that everything goes except bestiality, child pornography, incitement to drug abuse, terrorism and sexual violence. The question is whether the Telecom board agrees with that. Does the Government agree with that? Let us not get mixed up and confused by these mealy-mouthed statements about adults being free to view what they wish. That is a specious argument. Adults are not free to hear the anti-female propaganda of porn merchants unless it is published. The real issue is whether the Federal Government and the Telecom board should permit Telecom to act, in effect, as the publisher and agent of sexploit profiteers undermining the status of women in Australia.

That is the issue. What I want to ask is whether the Telecom board accepts the view that is expressed by Janet Strickland. Will Telecom appoint her as the arbiter in this area? What is the Government's view about that and the previous matter I raised?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I can only repeat the undertakings on the same matter that I gave previously. In respect of the two specific questions that Senator Harradine asked, might I just say that recommendation 2, for what it is worth-and it should be said because it is another point of view-expresses a position with which I am entirely comfortable. Senator Harradine finds it unacceptable and offensive. I daresay that there would be a whole host of people who, if someone else had been chosen to do this review who had adopted a very hard line on Telecom being a censor, would have been equally offended by that proposition. It is impossible to get something in this area that will satisfy everybody. That is absolutely correct. What some people would find offensive and highly disorderly and so on to an old bush boy like me might be just a matter of course. I just say that Janet Strickland will be one person out of seven on this committee.
—And they will all be tied by her guidelines, by recommendation 2.

—I have already canvassed that, with respect. I must say personally that being tied with bindings such as recommendation 2 is something that Senator Harradine and I again agree to disagree on. Senator Harradine finds that to be unacceptable; I find the recommendation worth reading out again, and I will do so:

SPEECH.PARA: That such standards attempt to give expression to the philosophy that adults should have the maximum freedom-
not total freedom-

TALK.START.PARA: —Some weeks ago I attended a conference on Senate committees and responsible government held in this Parliament House. The conference marked the twentieth anniversary of Senate standing committees. It was excellently organised and I would like to congratulate the Clerk of the Senate, Mr Evans, and his staff for organising such an interesting and valuable conference. SPEECH.PARA: The Governor-General, Mr Hayden, spoke to the conference dinner. His remarks on the lack of community knowledge of Parliament and our Constitution are the basis of the remarks I wish to make this evening. The Governor-General said:

. . . it would be nice to hope that one day Australians may grow up with the same passionate conviction about their Constitution, their history and their political institutions as people in the United States have in theirs.

I agree with the Governor-General. One reason there is such a passionate conviction among the United States public for their political system is, I believe, that both sides of politics there join together to honour their history, their great historical figures and their political institutions. Democrats and Republicans alike remember the Founding Fathers of the American Constitution, celebrate together most of the great events in their history, and honour the symbols of their nation.

It has to be said that at least one side of Australian politics-the Australian Labor Party (ALP)-is at best equivocal about some of the fundamental aspects of our political system; for example, the desirability of upper Houses and, indeed, the role of the Governor-General. I am not without hope that some of our more irascible Labor colleagues may come to have a greater affection for a system of which they are, after all, major beneficiaries. When one witnesses the enthusiasm with which the ALP in New South Wales is using the upper House there to defeat industrial legislation which would repeal some trade union privileges, one realises that it is possible we may see some stronger support from the ALP for upper Houses in the future.

Another reason why the public lack, in the Governor-General's words, `passionate conviction' about their political institutions is that parliamentarians themselves seem to care so little about their forebears and their contribution to building our political system. I illustrate this point by pointing to some serious omissions amongst the historical paintings on display in this Parliament House. Often the pieces on display are placed in areas that are not particularly prominent. The founders of our great Federation receive barely a mention. However, if it were not for the energies of individuals such as Sir Henry Parkes, Sir Samuel Griffith, Alfred Deakin, Andrew Clark, Sir Edmund Barton, Sir Richard Baker and Charles Kingston, the Commonwealth of Australia would not exist. Parkes, Deakin and Griffith are key figures in Australian history, as Jefferson, Franklin and Washington are in American history. I suspect that Australians know more about the founders of America than those of the Commonwealth of Australia. The Constitution of Australia has stood the test of time and has been described as providing the basis for one of the most successful federations in the world today.

It is interesting that when members and senators of the 1920s decorated their Parliament House they gave great prominence to famous Australians in King's Hall. The sculptor Montford was commissioned to make eight reliefs, which were inserted into the pillars in King's Hall. The eight great people were: Sir Samuel Griffith, the main draftsman of our Constitution and the first Chief Justice of the High Court of Australia; the Earl of Hopetoun, the first Governor-General; Sir Richard Baker, the first President of the Senate; Sir Henry Parkes, who is frequently referred to as the father of Federation; William Wentworth, statesman and campaigner for representative and responsible government in New South Wales; Sir Frederick Holder, the first Speaker of the House of Representatives; Sir Edmund Barton, the first Prime Minister; and Sir George Reid, the first Leader of the Opposition.

Only two of these famous men, Sir Henry Parkes and Sir Edmund Barton, have been honoured by the parliamentarians of the 1980s in their Parliament House. Certainly, portraits of the first Prime Minister of this country, Edmund Barton, and a notable second Labor Prime Minister, Andrew Fisher, hang on the wall above the stairs from the Main Committee Room foyer where they can be seen by a judicious craning of the neck. As yet there is no sign of Australia's great federalist and second Prime Minister, Alfred Deakin. Neither is there any sign of John Christian Watson, famous for being not only Australia's first Labor Prime Minister-if one excludes Premier Dawson's brief seven days in Queensland-but the first Labor Prime Minister in the world.

Labor colleagues should be concerned that the official portraits of the first Labor President of the Senate, Henry Turley, and the first Labor Speaker, Charles MacDonald, have ended up in the Department of Administrative Services storehouse in Fyshwick. The portrait by the well-known artist Joshua Smith of Sir William McKell, the distinguished Labor politician and former Governor-General, has also ended up in storage. By contrast, in the foyer of the Main Committee Room we have been able to find space for the very large contemporary paintings No by John Brack and Movement Nine by Roger Kemp.

The coming together of the six Australian States to form a federation is a remarkable story and is the real foundation on which this Parliament House is built. I think it is a great pity that the story of Federation is not marked by a permanent display in this Parliament House. I am aware, of course, that a number of temporary displays have been prepared and others are in the planning stage. From what I have seen the Senate staff has done an excellent job with displays. The Senate has already commenced a series of short term exhibitions entitled Towards Federation, which will be held during this decade to mark the milestones of Federation. This would be an appropriate time to consider a more permanent display.

There are, of course, some interesting items in this Parliament House-the relics from Westminster, symbolising our links to the mother of parliaments, and the Aboriginal petitions attract considerable interest from members of the public. Perhaps the two most important documents-an original Magna Carta and the Commonwealth of Australia Constitution Act-are of immense value but in my view could be better displayed and better explained.

The displays in the public area above the Members' Hall are of interest but far too limited for the range of visitors coming into this building. I invite my colleagues to walk around the public areas of Parliament House and note the lack of historical and institutional material on display. I further ask them to note that there is a great deal of area which could be utilised for permanent historical displays. Indeed, we seem to find room for a variety of temporary displays by outside bodies, doubtless with their own intrinsic merit but of little relevance to Parliament House.

Any examination of the private corridors would reveal vast areas which would certainly benefit from tasteful and well displayed institutional photographs. What has happened to the splendid collection of committee photographs which once hung in the old corridors of the provisional Parliament House?

We could find space in the main committee room-and a very impressive room it is at that-for the vast mural Red Ochre Cove by Mandy Martin. We could find no space for the photographs of the men and women who laboured long and hard to create the Senate committee system.

I believe that four matters now need to be addressed. First, steps must be taken to ensure that the founders of Australia are appropriately honoured in this Parliament House and are given their due prominence. Secondly, the key political events in our history should be marked in some way in this Parliament House, either by display or painting. At the very minimum, steps should be taken to ensure that the key events which led to Federation are prominently featured.

Thirdly, the art work which is currently made available to members should be widened to include important historical political themes. I have no doubt that many members, recognising after all that we are inhabitants of a political institution, would sometimes prefer to display material commemorating significant historical events. I recall, for example, a most interesting lithograph by the artist Charles Nuttall of the opening of Federal Parliament in 1901 which used to hang on the wall near the post office in the old Parliament House. Where is that famous lithograph today, I wonder?

Finally, some ordered process should be put in place to enable proper consideration of the matters I have raised here today so that a balance is struck between art and history. I recommend that an informal bipartisan committee of members and senators be appointed to make detailed recommendations to the appropriate Presiding Officers. Alfred Deakin ended his account of the Federal story by calling the formation of the Commonwealth a miracle. He said:

To say it was fated to be is to say nothing to the purpose; any one of a thousand minor incidents might have deferred it for years or generations. To those who watched its inner workings, followed its fortunes as if their own, and lived a life of devotion to it day by day, its actual accomplishment must always appear to have been secured by a series of miracles.

I conclude by saying that I hope that those who come after us in this Parliament House will regard our work with more interest than we have so far shown to those who devoted all their energies so that we could have a parliament for all Australians.
