In fact, it is prohibited from charging, quite rightly, entrance fees for the concerts it puts on in the Great Hall. As you know, Mr President, each one has been an outstanding success with people having to stand in the corridors on the first floor because of the enormous attendance in the main part of the hall.

TALK.START.PARA: —You will have to put on a matinee.

—If we were not going broke we would be able to put it on as a matinee, Senator. These performances have been put on for free. Unfortunately, we cannot even ask for a donation towards the program, such are the rules relating to the use of the Great Hall.

SPEECH.PARA: When the Canberra City Opera has put on performances in other commercial halls, for example in the School of Music, it has been able to do very well; in fact, it is able to survive when it puts on major productions. Dido and Aeneas was put on at the Australian National Gallery and was moderately profitable. Die Fledermaus, which was put on last year in the Canberra School of Music, made a modest profit. In other words, the Canberra City Opera has demonstrated an ability to be commercially sound in the great bulk of its ventures and to put on programs involving the community of Canberra both as the audience and as participants.

As a result of its success it is now being penalised by the ACT Administration. As I understand it, it has never received in its four or five years of life any assistance from the ACT Administration. One gets the impression that the ACT Administration has taken the view, `Well, if you have been able to get by for so long, you can continue to get by', even though it does far more for the community than the other organisation called Opera ACT which has been granted $50,000 in order to put on three performances of one opera. That $50,000 is to stage Tosca in 1991 and its productions usually are largely made up of people who come from outside the ACT area.

Because the ACT Administration apparently takes the view that the Canberra City Opera can struggle by and can, because of the dedication of the people who are involved, keep on putting in its own money to provide free concerts, to involve the people of Canberra and to be an artistic success, the ACT Administration is prepared to risk that and to direct all its funding to a body which has had very mixed results in the past, and certainly has not received either the audience or the critical acclaim that the local product has been able to produce. I am disappointed not only at the fact that the ACT Administration has given $50,000 to Opera ACT for its one production of the year, but also that that has been given at the expense of the Canberra City Opera.

There has been a range of correspondence in recent times. Sir William Keys, for example, is Chairman of the Board of Governors of the Canberra City Opera. He has written to the Chief Minister of the ACT saying that he is appalled at the recently announced decision of the Arts Development Board to deny any financial assistance at all to the Canberra City Opera. I share that view. I would like to join Sir William Keys in expressing my serious concern.

That concern is so great that a crisis meeting of the Canberra City Opera is to be held this week at the Canberra School of Music in lecture room 3. The reason I mention that is that I am hoping that some of those people who have benefited from the Canberra City Opera's performances will be prepared to come along or, at least, to express their support for the Canberra City Opera and their disgust at the refusal of the ACT Administration to provide any support at all.

This crisis meeting could well mean that the Canberra City Opera may have to-I do not want to pre-empt the meeting-substantially reduce its services to the people of the ACT. When I say its services, I mean its involvement as well, because this is one of the key things about the Canberra City Opera. The people of Canberra, through its choruses, through its orchestras and through involvement generally, are participating in the Canberra City Opera in a way in which they simply do not get an opportunity to involve themselves with Opera ACT which has been getting this funding, basically, ever since the Australian Opera ceased bringing its productions to Canberra.

One of the key reasons why the Canberra City Opera was asking for money for the coming year is because Colin Brumby, the Australian composer, has actually written an opera specifically for the Canberra City Opera. It was to produce the world premiere of it next year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you got a part in it?
—No, I think this is serious singing, unfortunately, and I have not been offered a part in that one.

SPEECH.PARA: A large number of outstanding singers are available in the ACT because of the efforts of the Canberra School of Music, particularly the department of singing. Honourable senators can tell how outstanding they are because of the remarkable achievements so many of them have had in being able to join the staffs of overseas organisations such as the Vienna Opera, the opera in London, and so on. This group has attained outstanding achievements. I will mention some of those who have done so well later.

The point I was trying to make is that Colin Brumby, who is a distinguished Australian composer, has written specifically for the Canberra City Opera, with the libretto by Tom Shapcott. One of the requests made by the Canberra City Opera was for funding to enable this modern Australian work to be produced and to have a world premiere in Canberra. The ACT Administration could find no money for that, but it could find $50,000 for an Opera ACT production of Tosca, to run for three nights, which will depend mainly on imported artists.

The Canberra City Opera has provided experience that is vital for the future of young singers in Canberra. Two of Canberra's sopranos are now apprentice principals in the Royal Opera House, Covent Garden. Two other sopranos are now also apprentice principal singers with the Vienna State Opera-I met one of them when I was in Vienna earlier this year. One of Canberra's tenors was this year presented with the United States of America Metropolitan Opera award for young singers. This season he is understudy to Luciano Pavarotti as Duce di Mantova in Verdi's opera Rigoletto at the Philadelphia Opera under the baton of Riccardo Muti. Another of our singers has just been awarded the Mozart prize by Richard Bonynge who was greatly impressed with the professionalism of a 21-year-old performer. All these singers gained their first stage experience here in Canberra under the auspices of the Canberra City Opera. The world is recognising their talent, such is their expertise and ability, but unfortunately the ACT Administration has been unable to recognise the vital need to fund-even in a small way-the Canberra City Opera.

Not only is the ACT Administration denying its funding, it is now also throwing it out of the disused school building where in the past it has been able to store its props. Not only is the ACT Administration throwing it out, it is also deciding that the time to throw out the Canberra City Opera from this disused primary school should be 30 November-in the middle of the examinations that the students in the department of singing at the School of Music are obliged to undertake. The ACT Administration is showing the same commitment, the same dedication, to killing off the Canberra City Opera, as it has shown in its refusal to fund it.

If I sound angry about this, it is because I certainly am. So far, a range of angry letters have been written to the ACT Administration. A full-page advertisement has been taken out by many groups who are curious about the nature of the funding. When we look at the role of some people who belong to the boards which are making recommendations and the fact that the associations in which they are involved continue to get large amounts of funding at a time when the Canberra City Opera cannot get a cracker, we wonder what on earth is going on.

I am very disappointed to see that the same appalling funding decisions that were made by the previous ACT Administration are continuing under the present one. All I can hope is that the Canberra City Opera will be able to survive. I fear for its future in view of the hostile, antagonistic, unhelpful attitude of the ACT Administration. I hope it is not too late for it to change its mind and at last do something to help this organisation which has done so much for Canberra and, certainly, which has done far more for the arts in this area than other groups in Canberra which are receiving substantial amounts of public money.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Kemp raised the question of the neglect of our constitutional history. I think that, as a society, that is certainly generally true. He particularly focused on the fact that here in Parliament House we do not seem to respect, by a provision of proper exhibition space and hanging space, some of the marvellous paintings and photos of our framers of the Constitution, Prime Ministers, Presidents of this chamber and Speakers of the other place. We do not give enough significance to those paintings and photographs which can, of course, stimulate so much memory of the history of this Federation.

SPEECH.PARA: It may be that I will take up Senator Kemp's challenge. The coincidence of 100 years of Labor Party history to be celebrated nationwide next year may be a very good opportunity to recover many of those paintings and photographs, from whichever storeroom in which they are held, which portray the Labor side of the story of this Federation. That is not meant by any means to be a partisan comment. I simply say it may be a catalyst from our point of view. Of course, the resurrection of the history of the formation of the Commonwealth of Australia is a matter of bipartisan concern. I am sure it will receive bipartisan support. Senator Kemp's suggestions ought to be taken up in that regard.

Senator Michael Baume has raised the question of the funding of the Canberra City Opera. It seems to me that the local Minister for Health, Education and the Arts, Mr Gary Humphries, has been very badly advised indeed. He is a man with an extraordinary range of complex portfolios. I take it that he has not had the opportunity to give proper attention to what really lay behind the recommendations which were apparently made to him and which he apparently accepted. At least, that is what he told me when I made a telephonic representation to him regarding this matter.

It is curious, as Senator Michael Baume has pointed out, that there seems to be an utter disproportion between the efforts of particular companies. For example, one company has received $50,000 to put on three performances of Tosca some time next year, while we have the continuous presentation of the highest quality singing for the Canberra community and, of course, for those beyond the Canberra community. I well recall several marvellous occasions in the Great Hall here in Parliament House. One was a very solemn and tearful occasion-not only on the part of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke)-when a special concert was held in relation to the terrible massacres in Tiananmen Square. The Canberra City Opera was called upon to fulfil a role there and it did so magnificently.

TALK.START.PARA: —Excerpts from the War Requiem of Britten.

—That is right-excerpts from the War Requiem of Britten, which were extremely moving and very well performed. A great sense of occasion was enhanced by their performance. On the other hand, of course, there have been occasions when, for the sheer pleasure of the inhabitants of Canberra and those parliamentarians who are up for Parliament, we have had wonderful Sunday afternoon concerts. One occurred during the Floriade festival which was held some five or six weeks ago.
—And the first anniversary of the opening of Parliament House.

—That is right. There have been a variety of occasions, even here in Parliament, when we have had an opportunity to witness the contribution of the Canberra City Opera to the artistic and cultural life of the nation's capital. For that reason, the funding decision seems to be extraordinary. One may wonder at the fact that the alternative company was engaged in recruiting, as I understand it, personnel to perform in Tosca well before the announcement was made by the Minister on the supposed advice of the funding boards. That raises the question of whether there was some sort of animus and some sort of prejudice, which lay behind the advice which was proffered to him. I do not say he shared that animus or prejudice, but I am saying that there was a nod and a wink very early in the piece which I think would need some further questioning.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Michael Baume has put the case very well. If Mr Humphries-whom I take to be an honourable man and a man with a concern for the arts, otherwise he would not have asked for this particular port- folio-wants to be remembered, he ought to be remembered not as the man who attended the second of three performances of Tosca some time next year but as the special distinguished guest at the world premiere of an Australian opera by Colin Brumby. That is the way in which he would be remembered by those who have any concern for the artistic and cultural life of this nation. He would certainly deserve the respect and earn the plaudits of both sides of this chamber. I want him to know that.

There would be bipartisan support if he found himself, on the receipt of better advice and on further reflection, able to fund the Canberra City Opera. Otherwise I share Senator Michael Baume's fear that David Parker and Marie van Hove will leave Canberra; that the group they have built up over a few short years will disintegrate without their marvellous enthusiasm and sheer skill and expertise; that what was the nucleus, indeed the flowering, of operatic and other excellent singing here in Canberra, the nation's capital, will disappear with them; and that we will not be able to have the sorts of functions, both solemn and for sheer enjoyment, that we have had in the Great Hall of Parliament.
For all those reasons, I ask the Minister in the local House of Assembly to give further consideration to this matter in the light of the representations that have been made tonight.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Kemp raised a number of interesting questions in his contribution tonight. I can assure him that I will refer his comments to my colleague Mr Speaker. I will do that because a number of issues concerning the art collection in this building are currently being considered by Mr Speaker and myself. I welcome Senator Kemp's remarks.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Sale of Human Organs in China

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 13 August 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Government aware of a report in the Australian by leading writer John Swain of Hong Kong that China is selling organs from victims of executions.

(2) In view of the seriousness of the report, can it be established if political protesters in the pro-democracy demonstration in Tiananmen square in 1989 had their organs removed after being executed; if so, what action, if any, is the Government taking to protest against this practice.
(3) Does the Government know if human organs are being sold by China to other countries.
(4) Does the Government know how many transplants Chinese hospitals performed in 1989.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. The article by John Swain alleges that the Chinese authorities have been using the kidneys and other organs of executed prisoners for transplant operations for overseas Chinese who have travelled to China for the operations.

(2) The Government is unable to confirm the substance of this article. However, similar allegations have been made from time to time in the Chinese language press in Hong Kong over a number of years, drawing on testimony from Chinese medical workers. It is not possible for the Australian Government to ascertain whether individuals executed following the events of June 1989, had organs removed for transplant purposes without their prior consent.

The Australian Government has clearly conveyed to the Chinese Government its universal opposition to the use of the death penalty in any circumstances. It has not specifically raised the issue of the use of the organs of condemned prisoners for transplant purposes with the Chinese Government. If the reports are confirmed, the Government would regard them with concern.
(3) The Government does not have information as to whether human organs have been sold by China to other countries.
(4) The Government does not have information on the number of transplant operations performed in Chinese hospitals in 1989.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, upon notice, on 22 August 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many students are currently in non-profit, non-government schools, approved for operation by State or Territory Governments, for which the Federal Government is not currently providing a federal per capita recurrent grant as a result of the provisions of the `new schools' legislation and regulations.
(2) What are the savings to the Federal Government from the nonpayment of these grants.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment, Education and Training has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The latest available data is for the 1989 academic year. For that year there was a total of approximately 2380 unfunded students (full time equivalent) in all non-government schools in Australia.

Of these, approximately 1180 were unfunded students in nonprofit, non-government schools approved for operation by State or Territory governments and which were receiving Commonwealth general recurrent funding. This number represents 184 primary and 996 secondary enrolments.
The remainder were students in schools which do not receive Commonwealth general recurrent funding. Of these approximately 900 were primary students and 300 secondary students.

It is not known which of these enrolments relate to proposals which were not approved for funding under the new schools policy, as this data is not collected for all such enrolments. Some unfunded schools have never applied for Commonwealth general recurrent funding.

(2) The amount of Commonwealth general recurrent funding for which each student would be eligible depends on the funding category of the school which the student is attending. This data is not available for unfunded schools because no funding category can be given to them.

Data is not collected on which unfunded enrolments relate to proposals which were not approved for funding under the new schools policy. No figure is therefore available on the savings to the Commonwealth in respect of such enrolments. However, based on the average grant for primary students in 1989 being approximately $1040 and for secondary students approximately $1400, the notional savings to the Commonwealth in 1989 resulting from approximately 1180 unfunded students in funded schools was an estimated $1.6 million.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health, upon notice, on 16 October 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Why have the Medicare offices at Kings Meadows and Mowbray within the township of Launceston, Tasmania, been closed.
(2) Does the Minister realise that there are large numbers of disadvantaged people in the outer suburbs of Launceston who will now find it difficult to travel to the inner city.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Community Services and Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The decision to close Medicare offices at Kings Meadows and Mowbray resulted from a rationalisation by the Health Insurance Commission, which administers Medicare, of its branch office network. In the current financial climate with high demands on limited resources, it was uneconomical to retain three branch offices within a four kilometre radius.
(2) Consideration was given, inter alia, to the availability of alternative Medicare offices within close proximity so as to create the least disruption and inconvenience to the public.

Coupled with the higher than average level of direct billing in both areas, no member of the public should be unduly disadvantaged by the closures.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, upon notice, on 22 October 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Government any plans to curtail the Country Areas Program which involves country schools throughout Australia.
(2) What control does the Minister have over the various states in their administration of the scheme.
(3) Does it require federal approval before any state can make changes to the program.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment, Education and Training has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. The Government has budgeted in 1991 for a maintenance in real terms of the 1990 level of funding for the Country Areas Program.

(2) &(3) The Government establishes guidelines for the program and the Commonwealth Minister is responsible under the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Act 1988 for determining variations to existing country areas eligible for funding. State Ministers are responsible for the administration of the program in accordance with the guidelines. State committees are responsible for the co-ordination of the program, and local and area committees oversee local activities and provide advice and assistance in planning, implementing and evaluating projects. Prior to the receipt of funding, a State is required to agree to abide by the provisions of the Act and, in general, the guidelines, which include the requirements for the State to apply the funds in accordance with the program objective, and to meet administrative requirements in the guidelines. Where a State does not meet a condition for funding the Commonwealth Minister has the power under the Act to withhold or delay payment of a grant.
